paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the DUKE, EGEON, JAILER, and other attendants$NEWLINE$DUKE$NEWLINE$EGEON$NEWLINE$JAILER
paragraphs.translated: The DUKE, EGEON, and the JAILER enter, with other attendants.$NEWLINE$DUKE$NEWLINE$EGEON$NEWLINE$JAILER

paragraphs.original: EGEON$NEWLINE$Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall,$NEWLINE$And by the doom of death end woes and all.
paragraphs.translated: EGEON$NEWLINE$Continue, Solinus, and bring on my downfall. Give me the death sentence and end all my troubles.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more.$NEWLINE$I am not partial to infringe our laws.$NEWLINE$The enmity and discord which of late$NEWLINE$Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke$NEWLINE$To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen,$NEWLINE$Who, wanting guilders to redeem their lives,$NEWLINE$Have seal’d his rigorous statutes with their bloods,$NEWLINE$Excludes all pity from our threatening looks.$NEWLINE$For, since the mortal and intestine jars$NEWLINE$'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us,$NEWLINE$It hath in solemn synods been decreed$NEWLINE$Both by the Syracusians and ourselves,$NEWLINE$To admit no traffic to our adverse towns.$NEWLINE$Nay, more, if any born at Ephesus$NEWLINE$Be seen at any Syracusian marts and fairs;$NEWLINE$Again, if any Syracusian born$NEWLINE$Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies,$NEWLINE$His goods confiscate to the Duke’s dispose,$NEWLINE$Unless a thousand marks be levièd$NEWLINE$To quit the penalty and to ransom him.$NEWLINE$Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,$NEWLINE$Cannot amount unto a hundred marks;$NEWLINE$Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Merchant of Syracuse, stop your begging: I’m not inclined to bend our laws. The hatred and discord between our two cities is the result of the bitter offenses your duke has perpetrated against the merchants of Ephesus, our well-behaved countrymen. Lacking the money to ransom themselves, these merchants were executed under your duke’s harsh laws, and this has erased all looks of pity from my face. Ever since these deadly conflicts erupted between your violent countrymen and ours, both you Syracusians and we Ephesians have held serious councils and decided not to permit any travel between our two hostile towns. No–the law goes further: if anyone born in Ephesus is seen in Syracuse’s marketplaces or if anyone born in Syracuse comes to Ephesus, that man dies, and his possessions will be confiscated by the Duke, unless he can raise a thousand marks to pay the penalty and ransom himself. Your possessions, even if we calculate their worth very generously, don’t even add up to a hundred marks. Therefore, by law, you are condemned to die.

paragraphs.original: EGEON$NEWLINE$Yet this my comfort: when your words are done,$NEWLINE$My woes end likewise with the evening sun.
paragraphs.translated: EGEON$NEWLINE$At least I have this comfort: when you finish speaking, my troubles will also end, at sundown.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause$NEWLINE$Why thou dep-artedst from thy native home$NEWLINE$And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Well, Syracusian, tell us–briefly–why you left your hometown and came to Ephesus.

paragraphs.original: EGEON$NEWLINE$A heavier task could not have been imposed$NEWLINE$Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable;$NEWLINE$Yet, that the world may witness that my end$NEWLINE$Was wrought by nature, not by vile offense,$NEWLINE$I’ll utter what my sorrow gives me leave.$NEWLINE$In Syracusa was I born, and wed$NEWLINE$Unto a woman happy but for me,$NEWLINE$And by me, had not our hap been bad.$NEWLINE$With her I lived in joy. Our wealth increased$NEWLINE$By prosperous voyages I often made$NEWLINE$To Epidamnum, till my factor’s death$NEWLINE$And the great care of goods at random left$NEWLINE$Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse;$NEWLINE$From whom my absence was not six months old$NEWLINE$Before herself–almost at fainting under$NEWLINE$The pleasing punishment that women bear–$NEWLINE$Had made provision for her following me$NEWLINE$And soon and safe arrivèd where I was.$NEWLINE$There had she not been long but she became$NEWLINE$A joyful mother of two goodly sons,$NEWLINE$And, which was strange, the one so like the other$NEWLINE$As could not be distinguished but by names.$NEWLINE$That very hour, and in the selfsame inn,$NEWLINE$A meaner woman was deliverèd$NEWLINE$Of such a burden, male twins, both alike.$NEWLINE$Those, for their parents were exceeding poor,$NEWLINE$I bought and brought up to attend my sons.$NEWLINE$My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys,$NEWLINE$Made daily motions for our home return.$NEWLINE$Unwilling, I agreed. Alas, too soon$NEWLINE$We came aboard.
paragraphs.translated: EGEON$NEWLINE$Asking me to speak of my unspeakable griefs–that’s the hardest task you could impose on me. But I’ll do it so that the world can see that it was natural emotion, and not a desire to break the law, that brought me to this fate. I’ll tell you whatever my sorrow permits me to say. I was born in Syracuse, and I married a woman–a fortunate woman, except for having been married to me. And yet I would have made her happy had our luck not been so bad. I lived with her in joy, and our wealth increased from the prosperous journeys I frequently made to Epidamnum. Then my agent died and, obligated to care for my now untended goods abroad, I was drawn away from my wife’s fond embraces. I hadn’t been gone for six months when my wife, almost fainting with the pains of pregnancy, made arrangements to follow me, and she soon arrived safely where I was. She hadn’t been there very long before she became the joyful mother of twin boys. It was strange: they looked so much alike that the only way to tell them apart was by their names. In the same hour, and in the same inn, a poor woman also delivered identical twin boys. Their parents had very little, so I bought the boys and raised them as companions and servants for our twin sons. My wife was more than a little proud of our two boys, and every day she would press me to return home. Reluctantly, I agreed–alas! Too quickly, we boarded a ship.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: A league from Epidamnum had we sailed$NEWLINE$Before the always-wind-obeying deep$NEWLINE$Gave any tragic instance of our harm;$NEWLINE$But longer did we not retain much hope;$NEWLINE$For what obscured light the heavens did grant$NEWLINE$Did but convey unto our fearful minds$NEWLINE$A doubtful warrant of immediate death,$NEWLINE$Which though myself would gladly have embraced,$NEWLINE$Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,$NEWLINE$Weeping before for what she saw must come,$NEWLINE$And piteous plainings of the pretty babes,$NEWLINE$That mourned for fashion, ignorant what to fear,$NEWLINE$Forced me to seek delays for them and me.$NEWLINE$And this it was, for other means was none:$NEWLINE$The sailors sought for safety by our boat$NEWLINE$And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us.$NEWLINE$My wife, more careful for the latter-born,$NEWLINE$Had fastened him unto a small spare mast,$NEWLINE$Such as seafaring men provide for storms.$NEWLINE$To him one of the other twins was bound,$NEWLINE$Whilst I had been like heedful of the other.$NEWLINE$The children thus disposed, my wife and I,$NEWLINE$Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixed,$NEWLINE$Fastened ourselves at either end the mast$NEWLINE$And, floating straight, obedient to the stream,$NEWLINE$Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.$NEWLINE$At length the sun, gazing upon the earth,$NEWLINE$Dispersed those vapors that offended us,$NEWLINE$And by the benefit of his wished light$NEWLINE$The seas waxed calm, and we discoverèd$NEWLINE$Two ships from far, making amain to us,$NEWLINE$Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this.$NEWLINE$But ere they came,–O, let me say no more!$NEWLINE$Gather the sequel by that went before.
paragraphs.translated:
We had sailed a
league away from Epidamnum before the sea, which always obeys the winds' commands, gave any indication of danger.$NEWLINE$league$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$We didn’t stay hopeful much longer: soon, the sky grew so dark that we were convinced we were going to die immediately. I could have accepted that, but I was forced by my wife’s incessant weeping–she wept in advance for the things that she saw ahead–and the piteous complaints of the sweet infants–who cried in imitation of the adults, without understanding why–to find a way to save us. Here’s the best I could do: the crew of our ship had fled for safety in the lifeboats and left us to sink with the ship. My wife, who was very concerned about the younger of our twins, tied him to a spare mast–the kind that sailors use for just such a purpose. She tied one of the other twins to him. I did the same with the remaining two boys. With the children taken care of, my wife and I tied ourselves to opposite ends of the mast and floated off, obedient to the current. It carried us toward Corinth–or so we thought. Eventually the sun, looking down upon the earth, burned off the threatening storm clouds. By the power of the sun’s wished-for light, the seas became calm. We saw two ships sailing toward us, one from Corinth, the other from Epidaurus. But before they reached us–let me say no more! You’ll have to imagine what came next, based on what had already happened.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Nay, forward, old man. Do not break off so,$NEWLINE$For we may pity though not pardon thee.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$No, keep going, old man; don’t stop like that. For we may take pity on you, even if we can’t pardon you.

paragraphs.original: EGEON$NEWLINE$O, had the gods done so, I had not now$NEWLINE$Worthily termed them merciless to us.$NEWLINE$For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues,$NEWLINE$We were encounterd by a mighty rock,$NEWLINE$Which being violently borne upon,$NEWLINE$Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst;$NEWLINE$So that, in this unjust divorce of us,$NEWLINE$Fortune had left to both of us alike$NEWLINE$What to delight in, what to sorrow for.$NEWLINE$Her part, poor soul, seeming as burdenèd$NEWLINE$With lesser weight, but not with lesser woe,$NEWLINE$Was carried with more speed before the wind,$NEWLINE$And in our sight they three were taken up$NEWLINE$By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.$NEWLINE$At length, another ship had seized on us$NEWLINE$And, knowing whom it was their hap to save,$NEWLINE$Gave healthful welcome to their shipwracked guests,$NEWLINE$And would have reft the fishers of their prey$NEWLINE$Had not their bark been very slow of sail;$NEWLINE$And therefore homeward did they bend their course.$NEWLINE$Thus have you heard me severed from my bliss;$NEWLINE$That by misfortunes was my life prolonged$NEWLINE$To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.
paragraphs.translated: EGEON$NEWLINE$Had the gods taken pity on us, I wouldn’t be here calling them merciless. The two ships hadn’t come within ten leagues of us when our ship hit a huge rock and split down the middle. As we were unjustly separated from each other, both my wife and I were left with something to delight in and something to sorrow over. For her part–the poor soul! Her half of the mast weighed less, but she was no luckier than I was: the wind carried her away more quickly. I saw them rescued by fishermen from Corinth–or so I thought. After a while, another ship rescued me and the two boys who were with me. The sailors knew me, so they took good care of us. Our ship would have caught up with the other ship and taken back my wife and the children, but we sailed too slowly and their ship sped toward their home. So now you’ve heard how I was separated from everything I love. It’s been my bad luck to remain alive long enough to be able to tell the sad stories of my own misfortunes.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,$NEWLINE$Do me the favour to dilate at full$NEWLINE$What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$And for the sake of those you grieve for, do me a favor: tell me the full story of what has happened to you and them, up to this point.

paragraphs.original: EGEON$NEWLINE$My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care,$NEWLINE$At eighteen years became inquisitive$NEWLINE$After his brother, and importuned me$NEWLINE$That his attendant–so his case was like,
paragraphs.translated: EGEON$NEWLINE$My youngest son, whom I care about the most, turned eighteen and started to wonder about his twin brother. He asked me to let him take his attendant–who had also lost a brother, though he had kept his brother’s

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Reft of his brother, but retained his name–$NEWLINE$Might bear him company in the quest of him,$NEWLINE$Whom whilst I laboured of a love to see,$NEWLINE$I hazarded the loss of whom I loved.$NEWLINE$Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece,$NEWLINE$Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia,$NEWLINE$And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus,$NEWLINE$Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought$NEWLINE$Or that or any place that harbors men.$NEWLINE$But here must end the story of my life;$NEWLINE$And happy were I in my timely death$NEWLINE$Could all my travels warrant me they live.
paragraphs.translated: name for himself–and go in search of him. I wanted to see my lost son as well, so I risked losing the one I loved in order to find the other. I’ve spent five years in the remotest parts of Greece and roaming all over Asia. On my way home, I came to Ephesus. I have no hope of finding my boys here, but I will check every place that is inhabited by men. But that is where the story of my life must end. I’d be happy to die if, in all my travels, I could prove that they are alive.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Hapless Egeon, whom the fates have marked$NEWLINE$To bear the extremity of dire mishap,$NEWLINE$Now, trust me, were it not against our laws,$NEWLINE$Against my crown, my oath, my dignity,$NEWLINE$Which princes, would they, may not disannul,$NEWLINE$My soul would sue as advocate for thee.$NEWLINE$But though thou art adjudgèd to the death,$NEWLINE$And passèd sentence may not be recalled$NEWLINE$But to our honour’s great disparagement,$NEWLINE$Yet will I favor thee in what I can.$NEWLINE$Therefore, merchant, I’ll limit thee this day$NEWLINE$To seek thy life by beneficial help.$NEWLINE$Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;$NEWLINE$Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum,$NEWLINE$And live. If no, then thou art doom’d to die.–$NEWLINE$Jailer, take him to thy custody.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Poor Egeon! Fate has decreed that you must endure the extremes of terrible misfortune. Believe me, if it weren’t against the law, my crown, my duty, and my position (which princes cannot disobey, not matter how they feel), my very soul would argue your case. But you are sentenced to death, and changing a sentence that’s already been passed would dishonor my title. However, I’ll do what I can for you. I will allow you one day to look for help in Ephesus. Call any friends you have. Beg or borrow to come up with the ransom. If you can, you live. If not, you are doomed to die. Jailer, take him into custody.

paragraphs.original: JAILER$NEWLINE$I will, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: JAILER$NEWLINE$I will.

paragraphs.original: EGEON$NEWLINE$Hopeless and helpless doth Egeon wend,$NEWLINE$But to procrastinate his lifeless end.
paragraphs.translated: EGEON$NEWLINE$Hopeless and helpless, I go my way, merely putting off my fatal end.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and FIRST MERCHANT$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$FIRST MERCHANT
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE,DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and FIRST MERCHANT enter.$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$FIRST MERCHANT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MERCHANT$NEWLINE$Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum,$NEWLINE$Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.$NEWLINE$This very day a Syracusian merchant$NEWLINE$Is apprehended for arrival here$NEWLINE$And, not being able to buy out his life,$NEWLINE$According to the statute of the town$NEWLINE$Dies ere the weary sun set in the west.$NEWLINE$There is your money that I had to keep.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MERCHANT$NEWLINE$So, tell people that you’re from Epidamnum–otherwise all your goods will be confiscated. Just today, a merchant from Syracuse was arrested for coming here. He couldn’t afford the ransom, so by law, he’ll be put to death before the sun sets. Here’s the money you asked me to hold.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host,$NEWLINE$And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.$NEWLINE$Within this hour it will be dinnertime.$NEWLINE$Till that, I’ll view the manners of the town,$NEWLINE$Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings,$NEWLINE$And then return and sleep within mine inn,$NEWLINE$For with long travel I am stiff and weary.$NEWLINE$Get thee away.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Dromio, bring this money to the Centaur Inn, where we’re lodging, and wait there until I come. It’ll be lunchtime within an hour. Until then, I’ll walk around town, peruse the markets, and gaze upon the buildings, and then I’ll return and sleep at the inn. I’m stiff and weary from all this travel. Get going now.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Many a man would take you at your word$NEWLINE$And go indeed, having so good a mean.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Many men would take you literally and take off with all this money.

paragraphs.original: Exit DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE exists.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$A trusty villain, sir, that very oft,$NEWLINE$When I am dull with care and melancholy,$NEWLINE$Lightens my humor with his merry jests.$NEWLINE$What, will you walk with me about the town$NEWLINE$And then go to my inn and dine with me?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$He’s a trustworthy servant. Often, when I’m dulled by worry and melancholy, he lightens my mood with his merry pranks. Listen, will you walk with me around the town and then dine with me at the inn?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MERCHANT$NEWLINE$I am invited, sir, to certain merchants,$NEWLINE$Of whom I hope to make much benefit.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MERCHANT$NEWLINE$Begging your pardon, but I’ve been invited to see some merchants, who I’m hoping to see a profit from. But if

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I crave your pardon. Soon at five o'clock,$NEWLINE$Please you, I’ll meet with you upon the mart$NEWLINE$And afterward consort you till bedtime.$NEWLINE$My present business calls me from you now.
paragraphs.translated: it pleases you, I’ll meet you in the marketplace at five and will keep you company until bedtime. Right now, my pressing business calls me away.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Farewell till then. I will go lose myself$NEWLINE$And wander up and down to view the city.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Farewell till then. I will go lose myself, wandering up and down throughout the city.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MERCHANT$NEWLINE$Sir, I commend you to your own content.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MERCHANT$NEWLINE$Sir, I leave you to your own contentment.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST MERCHANTexits.$NEWLINE$FIRST MERCHANT
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MERCHANT exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST MERCHANT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$He that commends me to mine own content$NEWLINE$Commends me to the thing I cannot get.$NEWLINE$I to the world am like a drop of water$NEWLINE$That in the ocean seeks another drop,$NEWLINE$Who, falling there to find his fellow forth,$NEWLINE$Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.$NEWLINE$So I, to find a mother and a brother,$NEWLINE$In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$He leaves me to my own contentment, but that’s the one thing I cannot find. Out in the world, I’m like a drop of water, trying to find a drop that matches in the whole wide ocean. When that drop fails its task–unnoticed, inquisitive–it dissipates into the ocean and destroys itself. In order to find a mother and a brother, I too have lost myself, unhappily.

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS enters.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS

paragraphs.original: Here comes the almanac of my true date.—$NEWLINE$What now? How chance thou art returned so soon?
paragraphs.translated: Here comes the man who shares my birthday. What is it? How is it that you’ve come back so soon?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Returned so soon? Rather approach’d too late!$NEWLINE$The capon burns; the pig falls from the spit;$NEWLINE$The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell;$NEWLINE$My mistress made it one upon my cheek.$NEWLINE$She is so hot because the meat is cold;$NEWLINE$The meat is cold because you come not home;$NEWLINE$You come not home because you have no stomach;$NEWLINE$You have no stomach, having broke your fast;$NEWLINE$But we that know what ’tis to fast and pray$NEWLINE$Are penitent for your default today.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Back so soon? Too late is more like it. The chicken is burning, the pig is overcooked, the clock has already struck twelve, and my mistress has clocked me one on the cheek. She’s hot because lunch is cold; lunch is cold because you’re not home; you’re not home because you’re not hungry; you’re not hungry because you’ve eaten already. But we servants—who know how to properly fast and pray—are being punished for your offenses today.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Stop in your wind, sir. Tell me this, I pray:$NEWLINE$Where have you left the money that I gave you?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Hold on a second. Answer me this, please: where’s the money I gave you?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$O, sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last$NEWLINE$To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?$NEWLINE$The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Oh, the sixpence you gave me last Wednesday to buy leather goods for my mistress? The saddle maker has it, sir—I didn’t keep it.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I am not in a sportive humor now.$NEWLINE$Tell me, and dally not: where is the money?$NEWLINE$We being strangers here, how dar’st thou trust$NEWLINE$So great a charge from thine own custody?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’m not in a joking mood. Tell me right now and stop fooling: where’s the money? We’re strangers here. How dare you let such a large amount escape your keeping?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I pray you, jest, sir, as you sit at dinner.$NEWLINE$I from my mistress come to you in post;$NEWLINE$If I return, I shall be post indeed,$NEWLINE$For she will scour your fault upon my pate.$NEWLINE$Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock,$NEWLINE$And strike you home without a messenger.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Please, sir; crack jokes over lunch. My mistress made me hurry here. If I go back without you, she’ll punish your faults by breaking my head open. I should think that your appetite would act like a clock (as mine does) and bring you home on its own, without the need for a messenger.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season.$NEWLINE$Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.$NEWLINE$Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$That’s enough, Dromio, please. This isn’t a good moment for jokes—save them till a happier time. Where’s the gold I gave you?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$To me, sir? Why, you gave no gold to me!
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Gave me, sir? You didn’t give me any gold.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness,$NEWLINE$And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Come on, you rogue. Quit joking. Tell me what you’ve done with the money I entrusted to you.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$My charge was but to fetch you from the mart$NEWLINE$Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner.$NEWLINE$My mistress and her sister stays for you.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$The only thing that I’ve been entrusted with was getting you from the market and bringing you to your house, the Phoenix, for lunch. My mistress and her sister are waiting for you.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Now, as I am a Christian, answer me$NEWLINE$In what safe place you have bestowed my money,$NEWLINE$Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours$NEWLINE$That stands on tricks when I am undisposed.$NEWLINE$Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Tell me where you’ve stowed away my money, or I swear I’ll break that comical head of yours for goofing when I’m not in the mood. Where are the thousand
marks you had from me?$NEWLINE$marks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I have some marks of yours upon my pate,$NEWLINE$Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders,$NEWLINE$But not a thousand marks between you both.$NEWLINE$If I should pay your worship those again,$NEWLINE$Perchance you will not bear them patiently.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I have some marks from you on my head and some of my mistress’s marks on my body. But between the both of you, I don’t have a thousand marks. If I gave those marks back to you, chances are you wouldn’t take them as patiently as I did.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Thy mistress' marks? what mistress, slave, hast thou?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Your mistress’s marks? What mistress do you have?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Your worship’s wife, my mistress at the Phoenix,$NEWLINE$She that doth fast till you come home to dinner$NEWLINE$And prays that you will hie you home to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Your wife, sir. My mistress. At the Phoenix. The one who’s waiting for you to come home for lunch and praying that you’ll get home quickly.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face,$NEWLINE$Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave. (beats DROMIO OF EPHESUS)$NEWLINE$(beats$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What, are you going to mock me to my face when I told you not to? There, take that, you scoundrel! (beats DROMIO OF EPHESUS)$NEWLINE$beats$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$What mean you, sir? For God’s sake, hold your hands.$NEWLINE$Nay, an you will not, sir, I’ll take my heels.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$What are you doing? Stop, for God’s sake! Well, if you don’t, then I’m out of here.

paragraphs.original: Exit DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS exits.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Upon my life, by some device or other$NEWLINE$The villain is o'erraught of all my money.$NEWLINE$They say this town is full of cozenage,$NEWLINE$As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye,$NEWLINE$Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind,$NEWLINE$Soul-killing witches that deform the body,$NEWLINE$Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks,$NEWLINE$And many suchlike liberties of sin.$NEWLINE$If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner.$NEWLINE$I’ll to the Centaur to go seek this slave.$NEWLINE$I greatly fear my money is not safe.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I swear, somehow the fool has been cheated out of all my money. They say that this town is full of deception—illusionists that can fool the eye, dark sorcerers who can bewitch your mind, soul-killing witches who can disfigure your body, disguised swindlers, fast-talking fakers, and all kinds of other unchecked sins. If this is true, then I’ll be leaving all the sooner.$NEWLINE$I’ll go to the Centaur to find this servant of mine—I fear that my money isn’t safe.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA$NEWLINE$ADRIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA and LUCIANA enter.$NEWLINE$ADRIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Neither my husband nor the slave returned$NEWLINE$That in such haste I sent to seek his master?$NEWLINE$Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Neither my husband nor the slave has returned, even though I sent the slave off running. Surely, Luciana, it’s already two o'clock.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Perhaps some merchant hath invited him,$NEWLINE$And from the mart he’s somewhere gone to dinner.$NEWLINE$Good sister, let us dine and never fret.$NEWLINE$A man is master of his liberty;$NEWLINE$Time is their master, and when they see time$NEWLINE$They’ll go or come. If so, be patient, sister.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Maybe some merchant at the marketplace invited him home for lunch. Sister, let’s eat and stop worrying. A man is master of his own freedom: time is his only master, and when the right moment comes along, he’ll come or go as he pleases. If this is so, be patient, sister.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Why should their liberty than ours be more?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Why should men be more free than women?

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Because their business still lies out o' door.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Because their business lies outside the home.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Look when I serve him so, he takes it ill.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Listen, when I behave this way toward him, he hates it.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$O, know he is the bridle of your will.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Oh, you should know that he’s the
bridle to your will.$NEWLINE$bridle$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$There’s none but asses will be bridled so.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Only a mule would agree to that.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Why, headstrong liberty is lashed with woe.$NEWLINE$There’s nothing situate under heaven’s eye$NEWLINE$But hath his bound, in earth, in sea, in sky.$NEWLINE$The beasts, the fishes, and the wingèd fowls$NEWLINE$Are their males' subjects and at their controls.$NEWLINE$Man, more divine, the masters of all these,
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Why, too much freedom leads to woe. There’s nothing under heaven that doesn’t have its limits. The beasts on the earth, the fish in the sea, and the birds in the sky are all subject to the males of their species and under their control. Men, who are nearest to God, are the masters of all these creatures. And men—the lords of the wide

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Lord of the wide world and wild wat'ry seas,$NEWLINE$Endued with intellectual sense and souls,$NEWLINE$Of more preeminence than fish and fowls,$NEWLINE$Are masters to their females, and their lords.$NEWLINE$Then let your will attend on their accords.
paragraphs.translated: world and the wild watery seas, gifted with intellectual sense and souls, greater than the fish and the birds—are the masters of women and their lords. Therefore, you should obey their wishes.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$This servitude makes you to keep unwed.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$It’s this servantlike mentality that’s keeping you unmarried.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Not this, but troubles of the marriage bed.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$No, that’s not it—it’s because of what happens in the marriage bed.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$But if you were married, you’d wield some influence.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Ere I learn love, I’ll practice to obey.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Before I learn how to love, I’ll learn how to follow orders.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$How if your husband start some otherwhere?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$What if your husband strays elsewhere?

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Till he come home again, I would forbear.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$I’d endure it until he came home again.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Patience unmoved! No marvel though she pause;$NEWLINE$They can be meek that have no other cause.$NEWLINE$A wretched soul, bruised with adversity$NEWLINE$We bid be quiet when we hear it cry,$NEWLINE$But were we burdened with like weight of pain,$NEWLINE$As much or more we should ourselves complain.$NEWLINE$So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee,$NEWLINE$With urging helpless patience would relieve me;$NEWLINE$But, if thou live to see like right bereft,$NEWLINE$This fool-begged patience in thee will be left.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Now that’s patience! No wonder she’s waiting to get married. It’s easy to preach meekness when you have no reason to act otherwise. When we’re faced with a wretched person, bruised and crying with hardship, we try to get them to shush up. And yet, if we were suffering the same kind of pain, we’d complain just as much—if not more! So you, who have no husband causing you problems, want to comfort me by preaching the virtue of feeble patience. But if you live to see yourself similarly denied your rights, this foolish patience will abandon you.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Well, I will marry one day, but to try.$NEWLINE$Here comes your man. Now is your husband nigh.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll get married one day, just to see. Here comes your servant—your husband must be coming soon.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS enters.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Say, is your tardy master now at hand?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Tell me, is your tardy master close at hand?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Nay, he’s at two hands with me, and that my two ears can witness.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$No; but he came at me with two hands—just ask my
ears.$NEWLINE$ears$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Say, didst thou speak with him? Know’st thou his mind?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Did you talk to him? Do you know his plans?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear.$NEWLINE$Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Yes, yes, he told me his plans on my ears. Damn his hands—I could barely
understand it.$NEWLINE$understand$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Spake he so doubtfully thou couldst not feel his meaning?
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Did he speak so ambiguously that you couldn’t get a feeling for what he meant?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Nay, he struck so plainly I could too well feel his blows, and withal so doubtfully that I could scarce understand them.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$No; he hit me very clearly and I felt his punches perfectly well. They were so dreadful, I could barely stand up under them.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$But say, I prithee, is he coming home?$NEWLINE$It seems he hath great care to please his wife.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$But please, tell me: is he coming home? It seems he has taken great care to please his wife.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Why, mistress, sure my master is horn mad.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Why, mistress, my master is as angry as a bull with horns.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Horn mad, thou villain!
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Horns? You bastard!

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I mean not cuckold mad,$NEWLINE$But sure he is stark mad.$NEWLINE$When I desired him to come home to dinner,$NEWLINE$He asked me for a thousand marks in gold.$NEWLINE$“'Tis dinnertime,” quoth I. “My gold,” quoth he.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I don’t mean he’s
cuckold mad. But he sure is angry. When I asked him to come home to lunch, he asked me for a thousand marks. “It’s lunchtime,” I said. “My gold,” he said. “The meat’s burning,” I said. “My gold,” he said. “Will you come home?” I said.$NEWLINE$cuckold$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: “Your meat doth burn,” quoth I. “My gold,” quoth he.$NEWLINE$“Will you come?” quoth I. “My gold,” quoth he.$NEWLINE$“Where is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?”$NEWLINE$“The pig,” quoth I, “is burned.” “My gold,” quoth he.$NEWLINE$“My mistress, sir,” quoth I. “Hang up thy mistress!$NEWLINE$I know not thy mistress. Out on thy mistress!”
paragraphs.translated: “My gold,” he said. “Where’s the thousand marks I gave you, scoundrel?” “The pig,” I said, “is burned.” “My gold,” he said. “My mistress,” I said. “Damn your mistress! I don’t know your mistress, the hell with your mistress!”

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Quoth who?
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Who said that?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Quoth my master.$NEWLINE$“I know,” quoth he, “no house, no wife, no mistress.”$NEWLINE$So that my errand, due unto my tongue,$NEWLINE$I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders,$NEWLINE$For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$My master said it. “I don’t know,” he said, “any house, wife, or mistress.” My message, which was supposed to be delivered with my mouth, ended up being carried back home by my shoulders. Because at the end of it all, that’s where he beat me.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Go back again, slave, and bring him home.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Go back again and be new beaten home?$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, send some other messenger.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Go back again, to be beaten home again? For God’s sake, send somebody else.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Go back, slave, or I’ll knock you one across the head.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$And he will bless that cross with other beating.$NEWLINE$Between you, I shall have a holy head.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$And he’ll add another knock across. With all these crosses, I’ll have a holy head.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Hence, prating peasant! Fetch thy master home.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Get out of here, you blathering peasant! Bring your master home.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Am I so round with you as you with me,$NEWLINE$That like a football you do spurn me thus?$NEWLINE$You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither.$NEWLINE$If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Do I treat you this roundly? You’re kicking me around like I’m a football. You kick me out, he kicks me back. If I keep working for you, I’m going to end up wrapped in leather, like a football.

paragraphs.original: Exit DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS exits.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Fie, how impatience loureth in your face.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Look at you! You have impatience all over your face.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$His company must do his minions grace,$NEWLINE$Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.$NEWLINE$Hath homely age th' alluring beauty took$NEWLINE$From my poor cheek? Then he hath wasted it.$NEWLINE$Are my discourses dull? Barren my wit?$NEWLINE$If voluble and sharp discourse be marred,$NEWLINE$Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard.$NEWLINE$Do their gay vestments his affections bait?$NEWLINE$That’s not my fault; he’s master of my state.$NEWLINE$What ruins are in me that can be found$NEWLINE$By him not ruined? Then is he the ground$NEWLINE$Of my defeatures. My decayèd fair$NEWLINE$A sunny look of his would soon repair.$NEWLINE$But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale$NEWLINE$And feeds from home. Poor I am but his stale.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$He feels the need to grace all his other tramps with his presence while I sit at home starving for a smile from him. Has homely old age taken the alluring beauty from my poor cheeks? That’s because he has squandered my beauty. Am I boring? Have I lost my wit? If my conversation is no longer free and clever, that’s because he’s dulled it—I’m like a sharp tool he’s blunted with a hard piece of marble. Is he charmed by their pretty clothes? Well, that’s not my fault—he’s the one in charge of my spending. What faults can you find in me that weren’t first caused by him? One smile from him would repair my decayed beauty. But like an unruly deer, he’s always trespassing past the park borders and straying away from home to feed in new pastures. I am nothing but a poor, used fool.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Self-harming jealousy, fie, beat it hence.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$This jealousy is harming only you! Drive it out of you.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense.$NEWLINE$I know his eye doth homage otherwhere,$NEWLINE$Or else what lets it but he would be here?$NEWLINE$Sister, you know he promised me a chain.$NEWLINE$Would that alone o' love he would detain,$NEWLINE$So he would keep fair quarter with his bed.$NEWLINE$I see the jewel best enamelèd$NEWLINE$Will lose his beauty. Yet the gold bides still$NEWLINE$That others touch, and often touching will$NEWLINE$Wear gold; yet no man that hath a name$NEWLINE$By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.$NEWLINE$Since that my beauty cannot please his eye,$NEWLINE$I’ll weep what’s left away, and weeping die.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Only someone who doesn’t feel this pain could tell me to ignore it. I know his eyes are worshiping some other woman, or why wouldn’t he be here? Sister, you know he promised to give me a necklace. I would gladly do without that if he would only stay faithful to me. Even the best jewel can be tarnished. Gold, however, can’t be corrupted—though it can be worn down if it’s touched too often. And no man with a reputation will tarnish that name with lies and bad behavior. Since my beauty no longer pleases my husband, I’ll weep away what’s left and then die with weeping.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$How many infatuated people go mad with jealousy!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE enters.$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up$NEWLINE$Safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave$NEWLINE$Is wandered forth, in care to seek me out.$NEWLINE$By computation and mine host’s report,$NEWLINE$I could not speak with Dromio since at first$NEWLINE$I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$The gold I gave Dromio is safe and sound at the Centaur, and the inn host says that Dromio has left and is looking for me. I haven’t spoken to him since I sent him away from the marketplace earlier. Here he comes.

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE enters.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: How now, sir? is your merry humor altered?$NEWLINE$As you love strokes, so jest with me again.$NEWLINE$You know no Centaur? You received no gold?$NEWLINE$Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?$NEWLINE$My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad,$NEWLINE$That thus so madly thou didst answer me?
paragraphs.translated: So, sir. Are you over your ridiculous mood? If you like being hit, crack some more jokes. You never heard of the Centaur? You weren’t given any gold? Your mistress sent for me to come to dinner? The Phoenix is my house? Were you mad when you spoke to me so madly?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What answer, sir? When spake I such a word?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Said what, sir? When did I say all that?

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Even now, even here, not half an hour since.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Just now. Right here. Less than half an hour ago.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I did not see you since you sent me hence,$NEWLINE$Home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I haven’t seen you since you sent me to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Villain, thou didst deny the gold’s receipt$NEWLINE$And told’st me of a mistress and a dinner,$NEWLINE$For which, I hope, thou felt’st I was displeased.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You moron, you denied having any gold, and you told me about a mistress and a lunch. And I hope you realized I wasn’t very happy about it.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I am glad to see you in this merry vein.$NEWLINE$What means this jest? I pray you, master, tell me?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’m glad to see you in such a merry mood. But what’s the joke? Please, master, tell me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?$NEWLINE$Think’st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that and that. (beats DROMIO OF SYRACUSE)$NEWLINE$(beats$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What, are you mocking me to my face? You think I’m joking? Here. Take that, and that! (beats DROMIO OF SYRACUSE)$NEWLINE$(beats$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Hold, sir, for God’s sake! Now your jest is earnest.$NEWLINE$Upon what bargain do you give it me?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Stop, sir, for God’s sake! Now this joke has turned serious. Why are you doing this?

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Because that I familiarly sometimes$NEWLINE$Do use you for my fool and chat with you,$NEWLINE$Your sauciness will jest upon my love$NEWLINE$And make a common of my serious hours.$NEWLINE$When the sun shines, let foolish gnats make sport,$NEWLINE$But creep in crannies when he hides his beams.$NEWLINE$If you will jest with me, know my aspect,$NEWLINE$And fashion your demeanor to my looks,$NEWLINE$Or I will beat this method in your sconce.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Just because I act familiar with you sometimes and let you fool around and joke with me, you try to take advantage of my affection. You pull pranks when I’m in a serious mood. You know, foolish gnats come out in the sunshine, but they creep back into their holes when it’s dark. If you want to crack jokes, first check what kind of mood I’m in and then adjust your behavior to suit me. If you don’t learn this rule, I’ll have to beat it into your sconce.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$“Sconce” call you it? So you would leave battering, I had rather have it a “head.” An you use these blows long, I must get a sconce for my head and ensconce it too, or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders. But I pray, sir, why am I beaten?
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You call it my “
sconce”? I’d rather call it my “head” so you’d stop battering it. If you keep pounding me, I’ll need a sconce to wrap my head with, or else I’ll have to keep my brain in my chest. But sir, why are you beating me?$NEWLINE$sconce$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Dost thou not know?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Don’t you know?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$All I know is that I’m being beaten.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Shall I tell you why?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Should I tell you why?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, and wherefore, for they say every why hath a wherefore.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Yes, and wherefore. You know the old saying: “Every ‘why’ has a ‘wherefore.’”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$“Why” first: for flouting me; and then “wherefore”: for urging it the second time to me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$“Why” first: for defying me. And then “wherefore”: for doing it a second time.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season,$NEWLINE$When in the “why” and the “wherefore” is neither rhyme nor reason?$NEWLINE$Well, sir, I thank you.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I don’t think any man’s ever been beaten for a “why” and “wherefore” that made so little sense. Well, thank you.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Thank me, sir, for what?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Thank me? For what?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Because you gave me something for nothing.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’ll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something. But say, sir, is it dinnertime?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Next time I’ll give you nothing for something. Is it lunchtime?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, sir, I think the meat wants that I have.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No. The meat lacks something that I have.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$In good time, sir, what’s that?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What would that be?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Basting.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$A basting.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Well, sir, then ’twill be dry.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Well, then it will be dry.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$If it is, I suggest you don’t eat it.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Your reason?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why not?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry basting.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Because it will make you angry, and that will get me another beating.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Well, sir, learn to jest in good time. There’s a time for all things.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Well, learn to make jokes at the appropriate time. There’s a time for all things.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I durst have denied that before you were so choleric.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Before you got so angry, I never would have thought that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$By what rule, sir?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why not?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father$NEWLINE$Time himself.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you: it’s because of a law as plain as Father Time’s bald head.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Let’s hear it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Let’s hear it.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$There’s no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$There may be a time for everything, but no man who has gone bald naturally can get his hair back.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$May he not do it by fine and recovery?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Can’t he get it by
fine and recovery?$NEWLINE$fine and recovery$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig, and recover the lost hair of another man.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Yes, he can pay a fine for a wig and then recover another man’s lost hair.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why is Time so cheap about giving out hair? After all, it’s plentiful in its growth.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts, and what he hath scanted men in hair, he hath given them in wit.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Because animals are blessed with hair. With men, he’s been stingy with hair, but he makes up for it by giving them intelligence.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why, but there’s many a man hath more hair than wit.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$But a lot of men have more hair than intelligence.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$And not one of them is smart enough to stop himself from going bald.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$So then, you must think that hairy men are honest and simpleminded.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$The plainer dealer, the sooner lost. Yet he loseth it in a kind of jollity.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$The more simpleminded they are, the sooner they
lose their hair. But they have a good time doing so.$NEWLINE$lose their hair$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$For what reason?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$For two, and sound ones too.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Two reasons. And good ones, too.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Nay, not sound, I pray you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not good ones, please.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Sure ones, then.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Then sure ones.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, not sure ones when we’re talking about something unsure.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Certain ones, then.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Then certain ones.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Name them.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Name them.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$The one, to save the money that he spends in tiring; the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$One, so they can save the money they spent on hairstyling, and two, so that when their hair falls out it doesn’t land in their dinner.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You were supposed to be proving that there isn’t time for everything.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, and did, sir: namely, e'en no time to recover hair lost by nature.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Right, and I did, sir. There’s no time to get back hair that’s fallen out.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$But your reason was not substantial why there is no time to recover.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You didn’t come up with a very good proof.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore, to the world’s end, will have bald followers.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Then I’ll change it to this: Father Time himself is bald, so for all time there will be bald men.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I knew ’twould be a bald conclusion:$NEWLINE$But soft, who wafts us yonder?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I knew you’d come up with a
bald conclusion. But wait—who’s that waving to us?$NEWLINE$bald$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA$NEWLINE$ADRIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA and LUCIANA enter.$NEWLINE$ADRIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown.$NEWLINE$Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects.$NEWLINE$I am not Adriana, nor thy wife.$NEWLINE$The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow$NEWLINE$That never words were music to thine ear,$NEWLINE$That never object pleasing in thine eye,$NEWLINE$That never touch well welcome to thy hand,$NEWLINE$That never meat sweet-savored in thy taste,$NEWLINE$Unless I spake, or looked, or touched, or carved to thee.$NEWLINE$How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it$NEWLINE$That thou art thus estranged from thyself?$NEWLINE$“Thyself” I call it, being strange to me,$NEWLINE$That, undividable, incorporate,$NEWLINE$Am better than thy dear self’s better part.$NEWLINE$Ah, do not tear away thyself from me!$NEWLINE$For know, my love, as easy mayest thou fall$NEWLINE$A drop of water in the breaking gulf,$NEWLINE$And take unmingled thence that drop again$NEWLINE$Without addition or diminishing,$NEWLINE$As take from me thyself and not me too.$NEWLINE$How dearly would it touch thee to the quick,$NEWLINE$Shouldst thou but hear I were licentious$NEWLINE$And that this body, consecrate to thee,
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Yes, yes, Antipholus: look bewildered and frown at me. You’ve given away all your sweet looks to some other woman—I am not Adriana nor your wife. There was a time when you’d freely tell me that words were never music to your ear unless I said them, that objects never pleased your eye unless I showed them to you, that touches never pleased your hands unless they were my touches, and that food never tasted sweet to you unless I had prepared it. How is it, my husband—oh, how is it—that you have become a stranger to yourself? I say yourself because you are a stranger to me now, but when we are indivisible and united in one body, I am better than the best part of you. Ah, don’t tear yourself away from me! For you should know, my love, that it would be as easy to let a drop of water fall into the churning sea and then fish it out again, unmingled and undiminished, as it would be to take yourself from me without taking me out of myself as well. How deeply would it cut you if you heard that I had been cheating on you and that my body—which is sworn for you only—had been contaminated by vile lust?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: By ruffian lust should be contaminate!$NEWLINE$Wouldst thou not spit at me, and spurn at me,$NEWLINE$And hurl the name of husband in my face,$NEWLINE$And tear the stained skin off my harlot brow,$NEWLINE$And from my false hand cut the wedding ring,$NEWLINE$And break it with a deep-divorcing vow?$NEWLINE$I know thou canst, and therefore see thou do it.$NEWLINE$I am possessed with an adulterate blot;$NEWLINE$My blood is mingled with the crime of lust;$NEWLINE$For if we too be one, and thou play false,$NEWLINE$I do digest the poison of thy flesh,$NEWLINE$Being strumpeted by thy contagion.$NEWLINE$Keep then fair league and truce with thy true bed,$NEWLINE$I live disstained, thou undishonorèd.
paragraphs.translated:
Wouldn’t you spit at me, and spurn me, and throw our marriage vows in my face? Wouldn’t you tear the mark off my
whorish forehead, cut the wedding ring off my finger, and swear to divorce me? I know you would, so go ahead. For I have, in fact, committed adultery, and my blood has been contaminated by lust. Because if marriage has made us one, then when you cheat, you poison my flesh as well—your contagion makes me a prostitute. So stay faithful to me and return to your marriage bed.That way, my reputation will be protected and your honor will be intact.$NEWLINE$whorish forehead$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Plead you to me, fair dame? I know you not.$NEWLINE$In Ephesus I am but two hours old,$NEWLINE$As strange unto your town as to your talk,$NEWLINE$Who, every word by all my wit being scanned,$NEWLINE$Want wit in all one word to understand.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Are you talking to me, fair woman? I don’t know you. I’ve only been in Ephesus for two hours. Your talk is as strange to me as your town. I’m trying with all my wits to figure out what you mean, but I can’t understand a word of it.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Fie, brother, how the world is changed with you!$NEWLINE$When were you wont to use my sister thus?$NEWLINE$She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Shame on you, brother-in-law! You’ve changed so much! Why are you treating my sister like this? She sent Dromio to bring you home for lunch.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$By Dromio?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Dromio?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$By me?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Me?

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$By thee; and this thou didst return from him:$NEWLINE$That he did buffet thee and, in his blows,$NEWLINE$Denied my house for his, me for his wife.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$You. And this is what you told me he said: that he beat you and pretended his house wasn’t his and I wasn’t his wife.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman?$NEWLINE$What is the course and drift of your compact?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Did you talk with this woman? What kind of scheme do you have going together?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I, sir? I never saw her till this time.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Me, sir? I never saw her till now.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Villain, thou liest; for even her very words$NEWLINE$Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You liar! You said those exact things to me back in the marketplace.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I never spake with her in all my life.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I never talked with her in my life.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$How can she thus then call us by our names—$NEWLINE$Unless it be by inspiration?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Then how does she know our names? By magic?

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$How ill agrees it with your gravity$NEWLINE$To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave,$NEWLINE$Abetting him to thwart me in my mood.$NEWLINE$Be it my wrong you are from me exempt,$NEWLINE$But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.$NEWLINE$Come, I will fasten on this sleeve of thine.$NEWLINE$Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine,$NEWLINE$Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state,$NEWLINE$Makes me with thy strength to communicate.$NEWLINE$If aught possess thee from me, it is dross,$NEWLINE$Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss,$NEWLINE$Who, all for want of pruning, with intrusion$NEWLINE$Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$How distasteful! That a man of your stature would scheme with his servant to upset me like this. It may be my fault that you’ve been avoiding me, but don’t make things worse by treating me with contempt as well. I’ll hang on your sleeve: you’re an elm tree, my husband, and I’m a vine. My weakness is enhanced by your strength, which gives me the strength to say this: the things that take you away from me are worthless—just overgrown weeds in need of a trimming. They get into your system and infect you, feeding off your confusion.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme.$NEWLINE$What, was I married to her in my dream?$NEWLINE$Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?$NEWLINE$What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?$NEWLINE$Until I know this sure uncertainty$NEWLINE$I’ll entertain the offered fallacy.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$She’s talking to me. She’s talking about me. What, was I married to her in a dream? Or am I asleep now and imagining all this? What is making our eyes and ears act so strangely? Until I know for sure, I’ll humor her.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Dromio, tell the servants to prepare for lunch.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$O, for my beads! I cross me for a sinner.$NEWLINE$This is the fairy land. O spite of spites!
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Oh, I wish I had my rosary! I’ll cross myself. This must be some kind of fairyland. Oh, spite of spites! We’re

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites:$NEWLINE$If we obey them not, this will ensue:$NEWLINE$They’ll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.
paragraphs.translated: speaking with goblins, owls, and demons. If we don’t obey them, they’ll suck the life out of us or pinch us black and blue.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Why prat’st thou to thyself and answer’st not?$NEWLINE$Dromio—thou, Dromio—thou snail, thou slug, thou sot.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Why are you mumbling to yourself instead of answering the order I gave you? Dromio, you drone, you snail, you slug, you idiot!

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I am transformèd, master, am I not?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’ve been transformed somehow, haven’t I, master?

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I think thou art in mind, and so am I.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I think your mind has been altered, and mine too.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, master, I’ve been changed in both mind and body.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Thou hast thine own form.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Your body looks the same.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, I am an ape.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, I’m an
ape.$NEWLINE$ape$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$If thou art changed to aught, ’tis to an ass.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$If you’ve changed into anything, it’s an ass.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$'Tis true. She rides me, and I long for grass.$NEWLINE$'Tis so. I am an ass; else it could never be$NEWLINE$But I should know her as well as she knows me.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$That’s true. She’s riding me hard, and all I want to do is get out of here. I must be as stupid as an ass—that’s why I don’t know her, but she knows me.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Come, come, no longer will I be a fool,$NEWLINE$To put the finger in the eye and weep$NEWLINE$Whilst man and master laugh my woes to scorn.$NEWLINE$Come, sir, to dinner.—Dromio, keep the gate. —$NEWLINE$Husband, I’ll dine above with you today,$NEWLINE$And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.$NEWLINE$Sirrah, if any ask you for your master,$NEWLINE$Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter.—$NEWLINE$Come, sister.—Dromio, play the porter well.
paragraphs.translated:
ADRIANA$NEWLINE$All right, all right. I won’t play the fool anymore and just cry while my husband and his man laugh at me. Come, husband, let’s go to lunch. Dromio, guard the door. Husband, I’ll eat with you in private today and hear your confession about all the pranks you’ve pulled.
Sirrah, if anyone asks where your master is, say he’s out to lunch, and don’t let anyone come in. Come, sister. Dromio, do a good job as doorkeeper.$NEWLINE$Sirrah$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?$NEWLINE$Sleeping or waking, mad or well-advised?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Am I on earth, in heaven, or in hell? Asleep or awake? Crazy or sane? These people know me, but I don’t

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Known unto these, and to myself disguised!$NEWLINE$I’ll say as they say, and persever so,$NEWLINE$And in this mist at all adventures go.
paragraphs.translated: know myself! I’ll agree with them and keep with it, whatever happens.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, shall I be porter at the gate?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, should I watch the door?

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Yes, and don’t let anyone come in, or else I’ll break your head.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Come, come, Antipholus, we dine too late.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Come come, Antipholus. We’re late for lunch.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, DROMIO OF EPHESUS, ANGELO, and BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$ANGELO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, DROMIO OF EPHESUS,ANGELO, and BALTHASAR enter.$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$ANGELO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all;$NEWLINE$My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours.$NEWLINE$Say that I lingered with you at your shop$NEWLINE$To see the making of her carcanet,$NEWLINE$And that tomorrow you will bring it home.$NEWLINE$But here’s a villain that would face me down$NEWLINE$He met me on the mart, and that I beat him$NEWLINE$And charged him with a thousand marks in gold,$NEWLINE$And that I did deny my wife and house.—$NEWLINE$Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Signior Angelo, please excuse us. My wife gets angry when I’m late. Here’s the story we’ll tell her: that I was with you at your shop, watching you make her necklace, and that you’re going to deliver it tomorrow. But here comes a scoundrel who says he saw me at the marketplace and that I beat on him, told him I’d given him a thousand marks in gold, and then lied about my wife and my house. You drunkard, what was that all about?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know.$NEWLINE$That you beat me at the mart I have your hand to show;$NEWLINE$If the skin were parchment and the blows you gave were ink,$NEWLINE$Your own handwriting would tell you what I think.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Say what you want, but I know what I know. You beat me at the marketplace, and I have the bruises to prove it. If my skin were paper and your punches were ink, you could read the beating on my body.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I think thou art an ass.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I think you’re an ass.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Marry, so it doth appear$NEWLINE$By the wrongs I suffer and the blows I bear.$NEWLINE$I should kick being kicked; and, being at that pass,$NEWLINE$You would keep from my heels and beware of an ass.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Honestly, it sure looks that way, judging by all the beatings and the bad treatment I’m getting. Since I’m an ass, I ought to kick like one. Then you’d be scared of me and keep away.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You’re sad, Signior Balthasar. Pray God our cheer$NEWLINE$May answer my good will and your good welcome here.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Signior Balthasar, you look upset. I hope the good meal I’m going to give you will show the goodwill I bear you and how welcome you are.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Your delicacies aren’t worth as much to me as your welcome is.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$O Signior Balthasar, either at flesh or fish$NEWLINE$A table full of welcome make scarce one dainty dish.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Signior Balthasar, all the welcome in the world can’t compare to a good meal, whatever kind of food it might be.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Good food’s not a big deal—everyone can afford that.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$And welcome more common, for that’s nothing but words.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$And everyone can say “welcome,” which is just a word.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$A little food and a huge welcome makes a joyous feast.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Ay, to a niggardly host and more sparing guest.$NEWLINE$But though my cates be mean, take them in good part.$NEWLINE$Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.$NEWLINE$But soft! My door is lock’d. (to DROMIO) Go, bid them let us in.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Sure, to a cheap host and an even cheaper guest. But look, even if my dishes are poor, eat them with my best wishes. You may come across better food, but not a warmer welcome. What’s this? My door is locked. (to DROMIO) Tell them to let us in.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Maud, Bridget, Marian, Ciceley, Gillian, Ginn!
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Maud, Bridget, Marian, Ciceley, Gillian, Ginn!

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb, idiot, patch!$NEWLINE$(within)$NEWLINE$Either get thee from the door or sit down at the hatch.$NEWLINE$Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou call’st for such store$NEWLINE$When one is one too many? Go, get thee from the door.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Dope, moron, eunuch, fool, idiot, clown! Either get away from the door or sit yourself down there! What, are you trying to summon women with your spells—is that why you’re calling out so many names? Isn’t one enough for you? Get away with you!$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$What patch is made our porter? My master stays in the street.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$What clown did they hire as the new doorkeeper? My master is standing out in the street!

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) Let him walk from whence he came, lest he catch cold on ’s feet.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Then he should go back where he came from so he doesn’t catch a cold.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Who talks within there? Ho, open the door.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Who’s in there? Hey, open the door!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) Right, sir, I’ll tell you when an you tell me wherefore.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Right. Give me one good reason and I will.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Wherefore? For my dinner. I have not dined today.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$A reason? So I can eat lunch. I haven’t eaten today.
