paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) Nor today here you must not. Come again when you may.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) And you won’t eat here today. Come again some other time.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$What art thou that keep’st me out from the house I owe?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Who do you think you are, keeping me out of my own house?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) The porter for this time, sir, and my name is Dromio.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) I’m the doorkeeper for the moment, and my name is Dromio.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$O villain, thou hast stolen both mine office and my name!$NEWLINE$The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame.$NEWLINE$If thou hadst been Dromio today in my place,$NEWLINE$Thou wouldst have changed thy face for a name, or thy name$NEWLINE$for an ass.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You jerk! You’ve stolen both my job and my name! True, the job never did me much good, and my name only ever got me in trouble. If you were the Dromio in my shoes today, you would have felt like you traded your head for a target and your name for the name of “Ass.”

paragraphs.original: LUCE$NEWLINE$(within) What a coil is there, Dromio! Who are those at the gate?$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: LUCE$NEWLINE$LUCE$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(from offstage) What’s all the commotion, Dromio? Who’s at the door?$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Let my master in, Luce.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Luce, let my master in.

paragraphs.original: LUCE$NEWLINE$(within) Faith, no, he comes too late,$NEWLINE$(within)$NEWLINE$And so tell your master.
paragraphs.translated: LUCE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) No way, he’s too late. Tell your master that.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$O Lord, I must laugh.$NEWLINE$Have at you with a proverb: shall I set in my staff?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Lord, this makes me laugh! I’ll come at you with the old proverb: “Should I make myself at home?”

paragraphs.original: LUCE$NEWLINE$(within) Have at you with another: that’s—When, can you tell?$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: LUCE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) I’ll come at you with another: “I’d like to see you try it!”$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) If thy name be called “Luce,” Luce, thou hast answered him well.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) If your name’s Luce, then I say: Luce, good answer!$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Do you hear, you minion? You’ll let us in, I hope?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Listen up, you slave. Are you going to let us in?

paragraphs.original: LUCE$NEWLINE$(within) I thought to have asked you.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: LUCE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) I was going to ask you that question.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) And you said no.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) But you already answered no.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$So, come, help. Well struck! There was blow for blow.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Come, help me bang on the door, master. Well done! We answered them, blow for blow.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Thou baggage, let me in.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You good-for-nothing, let me in.

paragraphs.original: LUCE$NEWLINE$(within) Can you tell for whose sake?$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: LUCE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Says who?$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Master, knock the door hard.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Master, knock hard upon the door.

paragraphs.original: LUCE$NEWLINE$(within) Let him knock till it ache.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: LUCE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) He can knock till it hurts.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You’ll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$If I break the door down, slave, you’ll be sorry for this.

paragraphs.original: LUCE$NEWLINE$(within) What needs all that, and a pair of stocks in the town?$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated:
LUCE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Why are we putting up with all this? The town’s got a pair of
stocks.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)$NEWLINE$stocks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$(within) Who is that at the door that keeps all this noise?$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Who’s making such a ruckus at the door?$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) By my troth, your town is troubled with unruly boys.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) I swear, this town’s plagued by troublesome boys.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Are you there, wife? You might have come before.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Is that you, wife? You could have come sooner.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$(within) Your wife, sir knave? Go, get you from the door.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Your wife, you scoundrel? Get away from the door.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$If you went in pain, master, this knave would go sore.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$If she punishes you, master, she’s sure to punish me.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Here is neither cheer, sir, nor welcome. We would$NEWLINE$fain have either.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$It looks like we’re not going to get food or welcome here.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$We argued about which was best, and now we won’t get either one.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$They stand at the door, master. Bid them welcome hither.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Master, your guests are just standing here. Tell them they’re welcome.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$There is something in the wind, that we cannot get in.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$There’s something strange in the air that’s keeping us from getting in.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.$NEWLINE$Your cake there is warm within; you stand here in the cold.$NEWLINE$It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$And if your clothes were as thin as mine, you’d really feel the air. The food inside is warm, but you’re out here freezing. It would make any man as mad as a bull to be betrayed like this.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Go, fetch me something: I’ll break ope the gate.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Go get me something I can use to break down the door.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) Break any breaking here, and I’ll break your knave’s pate.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Break anything here and I’ll break your head.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$A man may break a word with you, sir, and words are but wind,$NEWLINE$Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I’ll break words with you, sir. And since words are just wind, I’ll be breaking wind right in your face.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) It seems thou want’st breaking. Out upon thee, hind!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) It seems you’re the one who needs to be broken. Be off with you, you dog!$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Here’s too much “out upon thee!” I pray thee, let me in.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I’ve had enough of this “off with you!” Come on, let me in!

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(within) Ay, when fowls have no feathers and fish have no fin.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Of course—when birds have no feathers and fish have no fins.$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll break in. Go, borrow me a crow.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Well, I’m going to break in. Go get me a crow.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$A crow without feather? Master, mean you so?$NEWLINE$For a fish without a fin, there’s a fowl without a feather.—$NEWLINE$(to DROMIO OF SYRACUSE) If a crow help us in, sirrah, we’ll pluck a crow together.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$A crow without feathers? Master, do you really mean that? He said “when fish have no fins,” and you came back with a bird with no feathers. (to DROMIO OF SYRACUSE) If a crow gets us in, sirrah, then you and I will have a
crow to pluck together.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$crow to pluck together$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Go, get thee gone. Fetch me an iron crow.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I meant a crowbar. Get going already.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Have patience, sir. O, let it not be so.$NEWLINE$Herein you war against your reputation,$NEWLINE$And draw within the compass of suspect$NEWLINE$Th' unviolated honor of your wife.$NEWLINE$Once this: your long experience of her wisdom,$NEWLINE$Her sober virtue, years, and modesty$NEWLINE$Plead on her part some cause to you unknown.$NEWLINE$And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse$NEWLINE$Why at this time the doors are made against you.$NEWLINE$Be ruled by me; depart in patience,$NEWLINE$And let us to the Tiger all to dinner,$NEWLINE$And about evening come yourself alone$NEWLINE$To know the reason of this strange restraint.$NEWLINE$If by strong hand you offer to break in$NEWLINE$Now in the stirring passage of the day,$NEWLINE$A vulgar comment will be made of it;$NEWLINE$And that supposèd by the common rout$NEWLINE$Against your yet ungallèd estimation$NEWLINE$That may with foul intrusion enter in$NEWLINE$And dwell upon your grave when you are dead;$NEWLINE$For slander lives upon succession,$NEWLINE$Forever housèd where it gets possession.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Be patient, sir! Don’t do this! This will hurt your reputation and make your wife, who’s innocent, look suspicious. Look, you’ve known her a long time. She’s wise, serious, mature, and modest. All this suggests that she has a good reason for doing this to you. Let’s assume that she has a reason, which you don’t know yet: have faith that she’ll eventually explain why she shut the doors on you today. Listen to me. Be patient and leave, and we’ll all go to the Tiger for lunch. In the evening, come back alone and figure out this strange resistance. If you get violent and break in now, in broad daylight, people will talk about it. The common mob will presume things, and your untarnished reputation will be damaged—and that damage will last long after you’re dead. Slander passes from generation to generation, and once it sticks to a family, it’s there forever.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You have prevailed. I will depart in quiet$NEWLINE$And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.$NEWLINE$I know a wench of excellent discourse,$NEWLINE$Pretty and witty, wild and yet, too, gentle.$NEWLINE$There will we dine. This woman that I mean,$NEWLINE$My wife—but, I protest, without desert—$NEWLINE$Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal;$NEWLINE$To her will we to dinner. (to ANGELO) Get you home$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And fetch the chain; by this I know ’tis made.$NEWLINE$Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine,$NEWLINE$For there’s the house. That chain will I bestow—$NEWLINE$Be it for nothing but to spite my wife—$NEWLINE$Upon mine hostess there. Good sir, make haste.$NEWLINE$Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me,$NEWLINE$I’ll knock elsewhere, to see if they’ll disdain me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You’re right—I’ll go quietly. And even though I’m in a distasteful mood, I’ll work on being happy. I know a terrific wench. She’s beautiful and charming—a little wild, but also gentle. We’ll eat at her place. My wife has accused me more than once of misbehaving with this woman. I swear to her that I haven’t, but it doesn’t change anything. We’ll go to her place for lunch. (to ANGELO) Go get the necklace, which I’m sure is done by now. Bring it to the Porcupine, where this woman is. I’ll to give it to her, just to spite my wife. Hurry, good sir. Since my own doors refuse to admit me, I’ll knock somewhere else and see if they turn me away as well.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$I’ll meet you at that place some hour hence.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$I’ll meet you there in an hour.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Do so. This jest shall cost me some expense.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Do that. This little prank of hers is going to cost me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIANA and ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$LUCIANA$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA and ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE enter.$NEWLINE$LUCIANA$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$And may it be that you have quite forgot$NEWLINE$A husband’s office? Shall, Antipholus,$NEWLINE$Even in the spring of love thy love-springs rot?$NEWLINE$Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous?$NEWLINE$If you did wed my sister for her wealth,$NEWLINE$Then for her wealth’s sake use her with more kindness.$NEWLINE$Or if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth—$NEWLINE$Muffle your false love with some show of blindness.$NEWLINE$Let not my sister read it in your eye;$NEWLINE$Be not thy tongue thy own shame’s orator;$NEWLINE$Look sweet, be fair, become disloyalty;$NEWLINE$Apparel vice like virtue’s harbinger.$NEWLINE$Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted.$NEWLINE$Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint.$NEWLINE$Be secret-false. What need she be acquainted?$NEWLINE$What simple thief brags of his own attaint?$NEWLINE$'Tis double wrong to truant with your bed$NEWLINE$And let her read it in thy looks at board.$NEWLINE$Shame hath a bastard fame, well managèd;$NEWLINE$Ill deeds is doubled with an evil word.$NEWLINE$Alas, poor women, make us but believe,$NEWLINE$Being compact of credit, that you love us.$NEWLINE$Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve;$NEWLINE$We in your motion turn, and you may move us.$NEWLINE$Then, gentle brother, get you in again.$NEWLINE$Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife.$NEWLINE$'Tis holy sport to be a little vain$NEWLINE$When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Have you completely forgotten your duty as a husband? Antipholus, your marriage is still fresh and new, like the springtime—have the young shoots of your love already started to wither? Is the building of your love already in ruins? If you married my sister for her wealth, then for her wealth’s sake, treat her with more kindness. Or if your affection has already strayed to another woman, at least be stealthy about it. Hide your false love, blindfold yourself so my sister cannot read your faithlessness in your eyes. Watch what you say, and don’t let your own words give away your shame. Look sweet and act kindly—be attractive in your disloyalty. Disguise your misbehavior as integrity, and behave properly even if your heart is tainted. Though you are sinful, carry yourself like a holy saint. Be false in secret: why does she need to know? What foolish thief brags about his crimes? It’s doubly wrong to cheat on your wife and then let her see the offense in your eyes. When you do something shameful, it’s possible to put a good spin on it, but bad deeds are made worse by speaking of them. Alas, poor women! We’re so gullible, we believe it when you say you love us. Even if you love someone else in your heart, make it appear as if you love us. We follow in your orbit, and you have the power to move us. So, my sweet brother-in-law, go inside. Comfort my sister, cheer her up, call her “wife.” It’s a holy thing to lie a little when sweet flattery can smooth over trouble.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Sweet mistress—what your name is else I know not,$NEWLINE$Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine,—
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Sweet mistress—I don’t know what other name to give you, or how you’ve figured out mine—you seem as

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not$NEWLINE$Than our earth’s wonder, more than earth divine.$NEWLINE$Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak.$NEWLINE$Lay open to my earthy gross conceit,$NEWLINE$Smothered in errors, feeble, shallow, weak,$NEWLINE$The folded meaning of your words' deceit.$NEWLINE$Against my soul’s pure truth why labour you$NEWLINE$To make it wander in an unknown field?$NEWLINE$Are you a god? would you create me new?$NEWLINE$Transform me, then, and to your power I’ll yield.$NEWLINE$But if that I am I, then well I know$NEWLINE$Your weeping sister is no wife of mine,$NEWLINE$Nor to her bed no homage do I owe.$NEWLINE$Far more, far more, to you do I decline.$NEWLINE$O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note$NEWLINE$To drown me in thy sister’s flood of tears.$NEWLINE$Sing, Siren, for thyself, and I will dote.$NEWLINE$Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs,$NEWLINE$And as a bed I’ll take them and there lie,$NEWLINE$And in that glorious supposition think$NEWLINE$He gains by death that hath such means to die.$NEWLINE$Let Love, being light, be drownèd if she sink.
paragraphs.translated:
wise and graceful as the earth is wonderful and divine. Teach me how I should think and speak. My understanding is clumsy and human, riddled with errors—it is feeble, shallow, and weak. Reveal to me the hidden meaning of your words. Why would you have me betray the truth of my emotions and make my love wander in some other direction? Are you a god? Are you trying to remake me? Go ahead, I’ll yield to your power. But if I am myself, then I know for sure that your weeping sister is not my wife. I don’t owe her any duty—it’s you that I submit to. Oh, sweet mermaid, don’t command me to drown myself in the flood of your sister’s tears.
Siren, use your song to make me love you instead, and I will obey. Spread your golden hair over the silver waves, and I will lie down in it like a bed. If a man could
die in that glorious fantasy, then I think he would benefit by dying. Love is light and therefore floats—if my love is false, let me sink!$NEWLINE$Siren$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$die$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$What, are you mad that you do reason so?
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Are you insane, talking like this?

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not mad, but mated—how, I do not know.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not insane, but amazed. I don’t know how.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$It is a fault that springeth from your eye.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Your eyes are playing tricks on you.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$That’s because you are near me, and you’re as dazzling as the sun.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Gaze where you should, and that will clear your sight.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Train your eye on what you should be looking at, and you’ll see straight again.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Sweet love, I’d rather close my eyes than look at darkness.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Why call you me “love”? Call my sister so.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Why are you calling me “love”? Call my sister that.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Thy sister’s sister.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Your sister’s sister.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$That’s my sister.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$That’s my sister.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No,$NEWLINE$It is thyself, mine own self’s better part,$NEWLINE$Mine eye’s clear eye, my dear heart’s dearer heart,$NEWLINE$My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope’s aim,$NEWLINE$My sole earth’s heaven, and my heaven’s claim.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, it’s you: my better half. My eye’s clear vision, my heart’s most precious desire. My food, my fortune, my sweetest hope, my heaven on earth, and my entrance to heaven.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$All this my sister is, or else should be.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$My sister is all those things, or else she should be.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Call thyself “sister,” sweet, for I am thee.$NEWLINE$Thee will I love and with thee lead my life;$NEWLINE$Thou hast no husband yet, nor I no wife.$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Call yourself your own sister, because I want you. I will love you, and with you I’ll spend my life. You have no husband yet, and I have no wife. Give me your hand.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$O soft, sir! Hold you still.$NEWLINE$I’ll fetch my sister to get her goodwill.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Oh, wait, sir. Stay here. I’ll go get my sister and see what she thinks.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIANA

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE enters.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why, how now, Dromio. Where runn’st thou so fast?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What’s going on, Dromio? Where are you running so fast?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Do you know me, sir? Am I Dromio? Am I your man? Am$NEWLINE$I myself?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Do you know me? Am I Dromio? Am I your servant? Am I myself?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You are Dromio, you are my servant, and you are yourself.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I am an ass, I am a woman’s man, and besides myself.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’m an ass, I’m a woman’s servant, and I’m beside myself.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What woman’s man? And how besides thyself?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What woman’s servant? What do you mean, beside yourself?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, besides myself I am due to a woman, one that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will have me.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you. Besides belonging to myself, I belong to a woman. A woman who says she owns me, who won’t leave me alone, and who wants me.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What claim lays she to thee?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$How does she claim to own you?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, such claim as you would lay to your horse; and she would have me as a beast; not that I being a beast she would have me, but that she, being a very beastly creature, lays claim to me.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$The same way a person would claim to own his horse. And she wants me as a beast. I don’t mean that she wants me because I’m a beast, but that she, who is a beast, says I belong to her.$NEWLINE$I’m

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What is she?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What’s she like?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$A very reverent body, ay, such a one as a man may not speak of without he say “sir-reverence.” I have but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a wondrous fat marriage.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$She has a very significant body. You couldn’t even talk about it without saying,
“I beg your pardon.” My luck would be running thin if I ended up with her, although she’d make it a fat marriage.$NEWLINE$“I beg your pardon.”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$How dost thou mean a “fat marriage”?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What do you mean, a fat marriage?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, she’s the kitchen wench, and all grease, and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light. I warrant her rags and the
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Sir, she works in the kitchen, so she’s oily. The only thing I could do with her is to use all that oil as fuel in a lamp and then use that light to run away by. Her

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: tallow in them will burn a Poland winter. If she lives till doomsday, she’ll burn a week longer than the whole world.
paragraphs.translated: clothes are so oily, they’d burn through the longest winter. Even if she lives till the end of the world, she’d keep burning an additional week.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What complexion is she of?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What’s her skin like?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Swart like my shoe, but her face nothing like so clean kept. For why? She sweats. A man may go overshoes in the grime of it.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$It’s dark, like my shoe. But it’s not as clean. You’d be up to your ankles in how filthy it is.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$That’s a fault that water will mend.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Some water will fix that.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, sir, ’tis in grain; Noah’s flood could not do it.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, it’s permanent. Noah’s flood wouldn’t be enough water to clean it.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What’s her name?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What’s her name?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Nell, sir, but her name and three quarters—that’s an ell and three quarters—will not measure her from hip to hip.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Nell. But an
ell and three-quarters wouldn’t be long enough to measure her waist.$NEWLINE$ell$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Then she bears some breadth?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$So she’s wide?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip. She is spherical, like a globe. I could find out countries in her.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Her hips are as wide as she is tall. She’s round, like a globe. I could use her like a map to find out where countries are.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$In what part of her body stands Ireland?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What part of her body is Ireland?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, in her buttocks. I found it out by the bogs.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Her bottom. It’s near the
bogs.$NEWLINE$bogs$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where Scotland?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where’s Scotland?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I found it by the barrenness; hard in the palm of the hand.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$In the palm of her hand, which is covered in
calluses.$NEWLINE$calluses$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where France?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where’s France?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$In her forehead, armed and reverted, making war against her heir.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$In her
forehead, which is enormous because of her receding hairline.$NEWLINE$forehead$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where England?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where’s England?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I looked for the chalky cliffs, but I could find no whiteness in them. But I guess it stood in her chin, by the salt rheum that ran between France and it.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I thought her teeth might be like the
white cliffs, but they’re dark and stained. So I guess it’s her chin, which is separated from her forehead by all the sweat on her face.$NEWLINE$white cliffs$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where Spain?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where’s Spain?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Faith, I saw it not, but I felt it hot in her breath.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Honestly, I didn’t see it, but I felt it in her hot breath.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where America, the Indies?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where’s America and the West Indies?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$O, sir, upon her nose, all o'er-embellished with rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadas of caracks to be ballast at her nose.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Oh, sir, on her nose, which is covered with pimples, sores, and red welts. It points straight down at her mouth, which catches everything that drips from it.$NEWLINE$exotic jewels$NEWLINE$exotic jewels$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Where’s Belgium and the
Netherlands ?$NEWLINE$Netherlands$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$O, sir, I did not look so low. To conclude: this drudge or diviner laid claim to me, call’d me Dromio, swore I was assured to her, told me what privy marks I had about me, as the mark of my shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my left arm, that I, amazed, ran from her as a witch. And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith, and my heart of steel, She had transformed me to a curtal dog and made me turn i' th' wheel.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Oh, sir, I didn’t look down there. In conclusion, this witch said I was hers. She called me Dromio and swore I’d promised to marry her. She knew private things about my body, like the birthmark on my shoulder, the mole on my neck, and the huge wart on my left arm. I was terrified, and I ran away from her as if she were a witch. And I think that if I hadn’t been brave and strong, she would have turned me into a dog and made me her slave.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Go, hie thee presently. Post to the road.$NEWLINE$An if the wind blow any way from shore,$NEWLINE$I will not harbor in this town tonight.$NEWLINE$If any bark put forth, come to the mart,$NEWLINE$Where I will walk till thou return to me.$NEWLINE$If every one knows us, and we know none,$NEWLINE$'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack, and be gone.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Get going—hustle over to the port. If there’s enough wind for a ship to sail out tonight, I won’t spend tonight in this town. If a ship’s leaving, come to the marketplace. I’ll wait there for you. If everyone here knows us but we don’t know anybody, it’s time, I think, for us to pack our bags and take off.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$As from a bear a man would run for life,$NEWLINE$So fly I from her that would be my wife.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I’ll run from this woman who claims to be my wife as fast as I’d run from a bear.

paragraphs.original: Exit DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO$NEWLINE$SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE exits.$NEWLINE$DROMIO$NEWLINE$SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$There’s none but witches do inhabit here,$NEWLINE$And therefore ’tis high time that I were hence.$NEWLINE$She that doth call me husband, even my soul$NEWLINE$Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister,$NEWLINE$Possessed with such a gentle sovereign grace,
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Everyone who lives here is a witch. That means it’s high time for me to go. That woman who claims I am her husband—I loathe her in my soul. But her gorgeous sister, who’s so lovely and gracious, who’s so charming and who speaks so well,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Of such enchanting presence and discourse,$NEWLINE$Hath almost made me traitor to myself.$NEWLINE$But lest myself be guilty to self wrong,$NEWLINE$I’ll stop mine ears against the mermaid’s song.
paragraphs.translated: almost makes me want to stay here against my better judgment. I’d better stop up my ears against this siren’s song.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANGELO with the chain$NEWLINE$ANGELO
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO enters, with the necklace.$NEWLINE$ANGELO

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Master Antipholus.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Master Antipholus—

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Ay, that’s my name.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s my name.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$I know it well, sir. Lo, here’s the chain.$NEWLINE$I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine;$NEWLINE$The chain unfinished made me stay thus long.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$I know that, sir. Look, here’s the necklace.$NEWLINE$I was on my way to take it to you at the Porcupine, but it took a little longer to finish than I thought it would.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What is your will that I shall do with this?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What do you want me to do with this?

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$What please yourself, sir. I have made it for you.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Whatever you want—I made it for you.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Made it for me, sir? I bespoke it not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Made it for me? I didn’t order it.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.$NEWLINE$Go home with it and please your wife withal,$NEWLINE$And soon at supper time I’ll visit you$NEWLINE$And then receive my money for the chain.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You did—not just once or twice, but twenty times. Take it home and make your wife happy. I’ll come over at suppertime and you can pay me for it then.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I pray you, sir, receive the money now,$NEWLINE$For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You should take the money now. If you don’t, you might never see the money or the necklace ever again.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You are a merry man, sir. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You’re a funny man, sir. Take care.

paragraphs.original: Exit ANGELO$NEWLINE$ANGELO
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO exits.$NEWLINE$ANGELO

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What I should think of this I cannot tell,$NEWLINE$But this I think: there’s no man is so vain$NEWLINE$That would refuse so fair an offered chain.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I don’t know what to think about this. But what I do think is that nobody in his right mind would refuse to accept such a beautiful necklace when somebody offers it. I

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I see a man here needs not live by shifts$NEWLINE$When in the streets he meets such golden gifts.$NEWLINE$I’ll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay.$NEWLINE$If any ship put out, then straight away.
paragraphs.translated: guess there’s no need to be a thief in Ephesus.$NEWLINE$People come up to you in the street and hand you gold. I’ll go wait for Dromio at the marketplace. If any ships are sailing, I’ll get right on one.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SECOND MERCHANT, ANGELO and an OFFICER$NEWLINE$SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$ANGELO$NEWLINE$OFFICER
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND MERCHANT, ANGELO,and an OFFICER enter.$NEWLINE$SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$ANGELO$NEWLINE$OFFICER

paragraphs.original: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$You know since Pentecost the sum is due,$NEWLINE$And since I have not much importuned you,$NEWLINE$Nor now I had not, but that I am bound$NEWLINE$To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage.$NEWLINE$Therefore make present satisfaction,$NEWLINE$Or I’ll attach you by this officer.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$You’ve owed me this money since the Pentecost holiday. I haven’t pressed you for it, and I wouldn’t now except that I’m going to Persia and I need money for the trip. So pay me now, or I’ll have this officer arrest you.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Even just the sum that I do owe to you$NEWLINE$Is growing to me by Antipholus.$NEWLINE$And in the instant that I met with you,$NEWLINE$He had of me a chain. At five o'clock$NEWLINE$I shall receive the money for the same.$NEWLINE$Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house,$NEWLINE$I will discharge my bond and thank you too.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Antipholus owes me the exact amount that I owe you. Just before I ran into you, I gave him a necklace. At five o'clock he’s going to pay me for it. Please, come to his house with me. I’ll pay what I owe you then and say thank you as well.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS and DROMIO OF EPHESUS from the COURTESAN'S house$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$COURTESAN'S
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS and DROMIO OF EPHESUS enter from the COURTESAN'S house.$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO$NEWLINE$EPHESUS$NEWLINE$COURTESAN'S

paragraphs.original: COURTESAN'S OFFICER$NEWLINE$That labor may you save. See where he comes.
paragraphs.translated: OFFICER$NEWLINE$He saves you the trouble: look, here he comes.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$While I go to the goldsmith’s house, go thou$NEWLINE$And buy a rope’s end. That will I bestow$NEWLINE$Among my wife and her confederates$NEWLINE$For locking me out of my doors by day.$NEWLINE$But soft. I see the goldsmith. Get thee gone.$NEWLINE$Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$(to DROMIO) I’m going to the jeweler’s house. You go buy a piece of rope—I’ll whip my wife and her cohorts for locking me out of my own house. Wait a minute! I see the jeweler. Go, be gone with you. Buy a rope and bring it to me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I buy a thousand pound a year! I buy a rope!
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I buy myself a thousand beatings a year if I buy a rope.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS exits.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$(to ANGELO) A man is well holp up that trusts to you!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I promisèd your presence and the chain,$NEWLINE$But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me.$NEWLINE$Belike you thought our love would last too long$NEWLINE$If it were chained together, and therefore came not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$(to ANGELO) Good luck to any man who trusts you. I swore that you would come with the necklace, but neither you nor the necklace showed up. Perhaps you were concerned about being chained to me and so decided not to come.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Saving your merry humor, here’s the note$NEWLINE$How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat,$NEWLINE$The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion,$NEWLINE$Which doth amount to three-odd ducats more$NEWLINE$Than I stand debted to this gentleman.$NEWLINE$I pray you, see him presently discharged,$NEWLINE$For he is bound to sea, and stays but for it.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$All joking aside, here’s an invoice spelling out exactly how many carats the necklace weighs as well as the quality of the gold and the workmanship. The total due is about three ducats more than I owe this gentleman. Please, pay him immediately. He’s about to leave on a trip and he’s waiting for the money.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I am not furnished with the present money.$NEWLINE$Besides, I have some business in the town.$NEWLINE$Good signior, take the stranger to my house,$NEWLINE$And with you take the chain, and bid my wife$NEWLINE$Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof.$NEWLINE$Perchance I will be there as soon as you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I don’t have the cash right now. Besides, I have some business to take care of in town. Good signior, take this stranger to my house. Bring the necklace with you, and tell my wife to pay you the amount due. I might make it back in time to meet you.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Then you will bring the chain to her yourself.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$So you’ll bring the necklace to her yourself?

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$No, bear it with you lest I come not time enough.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$No. You bring it in case I can’t make it.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Well, sir, I will. Have you the chain about you?
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$All right, sir, I will. Do you have it with you?

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$An if I have not, sir, I hope you have,$NEWLINE$Or else you may return without your money.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$If I don’t, I hope you do. Or else you’ll leave without your money.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain.$NEWLINE$Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman,$NEWLINE$And I, to blame, have held him here too long.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Listen, please, give me the necklace. This gentleman’s ready to go. The wind is right and it’s high tide, and I’ve delayed him a long time already.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Good Lord! You use this dalliance to excuse$NEWLINE$Your breach of promise to the Porpentine.$NEWLINE$I should have chid you for not bringing it,$NEWLINE$But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Good Lord! You’re using this as an excuse for not showing up at the Porcupine like you promised. I should have reprimanded you then for not bringing it, but you started fighting with me first.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$The hour steals on. I pray you, sir, dispatch.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$It’s getting late. Please, sir, hurry up.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You hear how he importunes me. The chain!
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Antipholus, you hear how the man pleads with me. Give me the necklace!

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Why, give it to my wife, and fetch your money.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Give it to my wife, and get your money.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Come, come. You know I gave it you even now.$NEWLINE$Either send the chain, or send me by some token.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Come, come. You know I gave it to you just now. Send the necklace to her, or send me with a token that will authorize her to pay me.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Fie, now you run this humor out of breath.$NEWLINE$Come, where’s the chain? I pray you, let me see it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Damn it, this isn’t funny. Where’s the necklace? Let me see it.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$My business cannot brook this dalliance.$NEWLINE$(to ANTIPHOLUS) Good sir, say whe'er you’ll answer me or no.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$If not, I’ll leave him to the Officer.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$My business cannot wait for this delay. (to ANTIPHOLUS) Good sir, tell me if you’re going to pay me. If not, I’ll turn this man over to the officer.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I answer you? What should I answer you?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Pay you? What should I pay you?

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$The money that you owe me for the chain.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$The money you owe me for the necklace.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I owe you none till I receive the chain.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I owe you nothing until I receive the necklace.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You know I gave it you half an hour since.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You know that I gave it to you a half hour ago.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You gave me none. You wrong me much to say so.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You gave me nothing, and you wrong me by saying you did.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You wrong me more, sir, in denying it.$NEWLINE$Consider how it stands upon my credit.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$You wrong me even more, sir, by denying it. Consider how poorly this reflects on me.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$Well, officer, I charge you to arrest him.

paragraphs.original: OFFICER$NEWLINE$I do, (to ANGELO) and charge you in the Duke’s name to obey me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: OFFICER$NEWLINE$I will. (to ANGELO) And I order you to obey me, in the name of the duke.$NEWLINE$to

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$This touches me in reputation.$NEWLINE$Either consent to pay this sum for me,$NEWLINE$Or I attach you by this officer.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$This harms my reputation. Either pay this sum, Antipholus, or I’ll have this officer arrest you.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Consent to pay thee that I never had?—$NEWLINE$Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou dar’st.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Pay for something I never got? Go ahead, you fool. Arrest me if you dare.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Here is thy fee. Arrest him, officer.$NEWLINE$I would not spare my brother in this case$NEWLINE$If he should scorn me so apparently.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Officer, here’s your fee—arrest him. I would have my own brother arrested if he treated me so terribly.

paragraphs.original: OFFICER$NEWLINE$I do arrest you, sir. You hear the suit.
paragraphs.translated: OFFICER$NEWLINE$You’re under arrest, sir. You hear the charges.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I do obey thee till I give thee bail.$NEWLINE$But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear$NEWLINE$As all the metal in your shop will answer.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I’ll obey you until I can make bail. But Angelo, you’ll pay for this, even if it costs all the precious metals in your jewelry shop.

paragraphs.original: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Sir, sir, I will have law in Ephesus,$NEWLINE$To your notorious shame, I doubt it not.
paragraphs.translated: ANGELO$NEWLINE$Sir, the laws of Ephesus will be on my side, and you’ll be embarrassed. I’m certain of it.

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE enters.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, there is a bark of Epidamnum$NEWLINE$That stays but till her owner comes aboard,$NEWLINE$And then, sir, she bears away. Our fraughtage, sir,$NEWLINE$I have conveyed aboard, and I have bought$NEWLINE$The oil, the balsamum and aqua vitae.$NEWLINE$The ship is in her trim; the merry wind$NEWLINE$Blows fair from land. They stay for naught at all$NEWLINE$But for their owner, master, and yourself.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, there’s a ship from Epidamnum that’s going to set sail as soon as its owner gets on board. I’ve left our luggage on the ship, and I bought the oil, balm, and liquor you wanted. The ship is ready, the wind is up, and the sailors are only waiting for their owner and for you.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$How now? A madman? Why, thou peevish sheep,$NEWLINE$What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$What are you, a madman? You annoying idiot, what Epidamnum ship is waiting for me?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$A ship you sent me to find, to book passage out of here.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope$NEWLINE$And told thee to what purpose and what end.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You drunken slave, I sent you for a rope, and I told you what to do with it.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You sent me for a rope’s end as soon.$NEWLINE$You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Yeah, right—you sent me to get whipped. You sent me to the port to find a ship.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I will debate this matter at more leisure$NEWLINE$And teach your ears to list me with more heed.$NEWLINE$To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight.$NEWLINE$Give her this key, and tell her in the desk$NEWLINE$That’s cover’d o'er with Turkish tapestry$NEWLINE$There is a purse of ducats. Let her send it.$NEWLINE$Tell her I am arrested in the street,$NEWLINE$And that shall bail me. Hie thee, slave. Begone.—$NEWLINE$On, officer, to prison till it come.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I’ll debate this with you later, and then I’ll teach you to listen more carefully. Go to Adriana, you scoundrel, and quickly. Give her this key, and tell her that there’s money in the desk that’s covered with a Turkish tapestry. Have her send it to me. Tell her that I’ve been arrested and the money will be my bail. Hurry, you slave! Go! Officer, take me to prison until the money comes.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SECOND MERCHANT, ANGELO, OFFICER, and ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$ANGELO$NEWLINE$OFFICER$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MERCHANT, ANGELO, OFFICER, and ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS exit.$NEWLINE$SECOND MERCHANT$NEWLINE$ANGELO$NEWLINE$OFFICER$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$To Adriana. That is where we dined,$NEWLINE$Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband.$NEWLINE$She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.$NEWLINE$Thither I must, although against my will,$NEWLINE$For servants must their masters' minds fulfill.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$To Adriana? That’s where we had lunch. Where that “sweetheart” said I was her husband! She’s too much for me to handle. But I must go there, against my will: servants must fulfill their masters' wishes.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA$NEWLINE$ADRIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA and LUCIANA enter.$NEWLINE$ADRIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Ah, Luciana, did he tempt thee so?$NEWLINE$Mightst thou perceive austerely in his eye$NEWLINE$That he did plead in earnest, yea or no?$NEWLINE$Looked he or red or pale, or sad or merrily?$NEWLINE$What observation mad’st thou in this case$NEWLINE$Of his heart’s meteors tilting in his face?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Oh, Luciana, did he tempt you like that? Could you tell from his face if he was serious? Yes or no? Did he look flushed or pale? Sad or happy? Could you tell from his looks what he was feeling in his heart?

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$First he denied you had in him no right.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$First, he said you had no right to him.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$He meant he did me none; the more my spite.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$He meant he did nothing right for me—which is true, unfortunately.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Then swore he that he was a stranger here.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Then he swore he was a stranger here.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$And true he swore, though yet forsworn he were.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$And that’s true—he is being strange. And yet he lies as well, for he’s no stranger.$NEWLINE$is

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Then pleaded I for you.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Then I pleaded for you.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$And what said he?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$And what did he say?

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$That love i begged for you he begged of me.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$That he felt for me the love that I begged him to feel for you.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$How did he try to persuade you to love him?

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$With words that in an honest suit might move.$NEWLINE$First he did praise my beauty, then my speech.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$With words that—if they were spoken honestly—might have moved me. First, he praised my beauty, then my eloquence.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Did’st speak him fair?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Did you praise him as well?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Have patience, I beseech.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Have some patience, please.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$I cannot, nor I will not hold me still;$NEWLINE$My tongue, though not my heart, shall have his will.$NEWLINE$He is deformèd, crooked, old, and sere,$NEWLINE$Ill-faced, worse-bodied, shapeless everywhere,$NEWLINE$Vicious, ungentle, foolish, blunt, unkind,$NEWLINE$Stigmatical in making, worse in mind.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$I cannot and I will not keep quiet. My voice will have its way, even if my heart can’t. He is misshapen, crooked, old, and withered. His face is ugly, and his body is even worse—all shapeless, everywhere. He is vicious, mean, foolish, blunt, unkind. His body is deformed, and his mind is worse.

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Who would be jealous, then, of such a one?$NEWLINE$No evil lost is wailed when it is gone.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$Then why be jealous of a person like that? When an evil thing has been lost, no one cries.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Ah, but I think him better than I say,$NEWLINE$And yet would herein others' eyes were worse.$NEWLINE$Far from her nest the lapwing cries away.$NEWLINE$My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Oh, but I think of him more highly than I say I do—and I wish he looked worse in other women’s eyes. I’m like a lapwing, creating a diversion in order to distract predators from my nest. My heart adores him, even though my tongue curses him.

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, running$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE enters, running.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Here, go—the desk, the purse! Sweet, now make haste.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Here! Go! The desk! Money! Come on, now! Hurry!

paragraphs.original: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$How hast thou lost thy breath?
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA$NEWLINE$How did you lose your breath?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$By running fast.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$By running fast.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Where is thy master, Dromio? Is he well?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Where’s your master, Dromio? Is he all right?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, he’s in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.$NEWLINE$A devil in an everlasting garment hath him,$NEWLINE$One whose hard heart is buttoned up with steel;$NEWLINE$A fiend, a fury, pitiless and rough;$NEWLINE$A wolf, nay, worse, a fellow all in buff;$NEWLINE$A back-friend, a shoulder clapper, one that countermands
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, he’s in a place worse than hell. A devil in a tough uniform has him—a man whose heart is as hard as steel. A fiend and a goblin, pitiless and rough. A wolf—no, even worse—a man all in tough leather. A backbiting friend, one who grabs people, who patrols the streets and passageways. A hunting dog that runs in

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The passages of alleys, creeks, and narrow lands;$NEWLINE$A hound that runs counter and yet draws dryfoot well,$NEWLINE$One that before the judgment carries poor souls to hell.
paragraphs.translated: the opposite direction of its prey, yet can follow the scent of the hunt. A man who puts people away before the verdict is announced.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Why, man, what is the matter?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Speak, man, what’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I do not know the matter. He is ’rested on the case.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I don’t know what the matter is, but he’s been arrested for it.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$What, is he arrested? Tell me at whose suit.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$What? He’s been arrested? Tell me, who had him arrested?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I know not at whose suit he is arrested well,$NEWLINE$But he’s in a suit of buff which ’rested him; that can I tell.$NEWLINE$Will you send him, mistress, redemption—the money in his$NEWLINE$desk?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I don’t know who had him arrested, but the man that arrested him was in a suit of leather. Mistress, will you send him bail? The money in the desk?

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Go fetch it, sister.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Get it, sister.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIANA$NEWLINE$LUCIANA
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIANA

paragraphs.original: This I wonder at,$NEWLINE$That he, unknown to me, should be in debt.$NEWLINE$Tell me, was he arrested on a band?
paragraphs.translated:
I don’t understand it. How could he be in debt without me knowing it? Tell me, was he arrested because of a
band ?$NEWLINE$band$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not on a band, but on a stronger thing:$NEWLINE$A chain, a chain. Do you not hear it ring?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not for a band, but for something stronger: a necklace, a necklace! Don’t you hear it ring?

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$What, the chain?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$What, the necklace?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, no, the bell. 'Tis time that I were gone.$NEWLINE$It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, no, the bell. It’s time for me to go. It was two o'clock when I left him, and now it’s one.

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$The hours come back. That did I never hear.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Time’s running backward? I’ve never heard of that.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$O yes, if any hour meet a sergeant, he turns back for$NEWLINE$very fear.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Oh, sure. When an
hour meets a cop, it turns and runs in fear.$NEWLINE$hour$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$As if time were in debt. How fondly dost thou reason!
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Time’s not the one in debt. Your logic is so foolish.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Time is a very bankrout and owes more than he’s worth to$NEWLINE$season.$NEWLINE$Nay, he’s a thief too. Have you not heard men say$NEWLINE$That time comes stealing on by night and day?$NEWLINE$If he be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way,$NEWLINE$Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Time is always bankrupt: it owes more than it can ever pay back in a season. And Time’s a thief, too—don’t you know the old saying, “Time steals along”? So if Time is in debt and also a thief, and a cop comes, don’t you think Time would turn back an hour?

paragraphs.original: Re-enter LUCIANA with a purse$NEWLINE$LUCIANA
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANA returns with a purse full of money.$NEWLINE$LUCIANA

paragraphs.original: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Go, Dromio. There’s the money. Bear it straight,$NEWLINE$And bring thy master home immediately.$NEWLINE$Come, sister, I am pressed down with conceit:$NEWLINE$Conceit, my comfort and my injury.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIANA$NEWLINE$Here’s the money, Dromio. Take it to your master and bring him home immediately. Come, sister, my imagination is too much for me: it both comforts me and depresses me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE enters.$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$There’s not a man I meet but doth salute me$NEWLINE$As if I were their well-acquainted friend,$NEWLINE$And every one doth call me by my name.$NEWLINE$Some tender money to me; some invite me;$NEWLINE$Some other give me thanks for kindnesses;$NEWLINE$Some offer me commodities to buy.$NEWLINE$Even now a tailor called me in his shop$NEWLINE$And showed me silks that he had bought for me,$NEWLINE$And therewithal took measure of my body.$NEWLINE$Sure, these are but imaginary wiles,$NEWLINE$And lapland sorcerers inhabit here.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Every person I meet greets me like an old friend, and every one of them knows my name. Some of them give me money, some invite me places, some thank me for the kind things I’ve done for them, some try to sell me things. Just now a tailor showed me fabrics he bought especially for me and then started to take my measurements. These are tricks of the imagination, and this place is filled with magicians.

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE enters.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, here’s The gold you sent me for. What, have you got the picture of old Adam new-appareled?
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Here’s the money you wanted, master. Hey, have you gotten rid of that
Adam?$NEWLINE$Adam$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What gold is this? What Adam dost thou mean?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What gold is this? Who’s this Adam you speak of?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not that Adam that kept the Paradise, but that Adam that keeps the prison; he that goes in the calf’s skin that was killed for the Prodigal; he that came behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Not the Adam from the garden of Eden, but the Adam from the jailhouse. The one that wears leather clothes. The one that grabbed you and arrested you.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I understand thee not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$I don’t know what you’re talking about.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No? Why, ’tis a plain case: he that went, like a bass viol in a case of leather; the man, sir, that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob and ’rests them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed men and gives them suits of durance; he that sets up his rest to do more exploits with his mace than a morris-pike.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No? It’s plain enough. The Adam who looks like a cello, in a big leather case. The one who gives tired people “arrest.” The one who gives ruined men new suits—law suits. The one who’s determined to do more damage with his nightstick than a soldier does with his pike.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$What, thou meanest an officer?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$You mean an officer?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that thinks a man always going to bed and says “God give you good rest.”
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Yes, the leader of the team; the one that gets you if you can’t pay a debt; the one who assumes people are always going to bed and says to them, “Have arrest.”

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any ships put forth tonight? May we be gone?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Well, sir, stop your joking there. Are any ships leaving tonight? Can we go?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that the bark Expedition put forth tonight, and then were you hindered by the sergeant to tarry for the hoy Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliver you.$NEWLINE$Expedition$NEWLINE$Delay
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why, sir, I told you an hour ago that the good ship Expedition was leaving tonight, but then the officer got you, and you decided to wait for the little rowboat Delay. Here’s the bail money you sent me to get.$NEWLINE$Expedition$NEWLINE$Delay

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$The fellow is distract, and so am I,$NEWLINE$And here we wander in illusions.$NEWLINE$Some blessed power deliver us from hence!
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$This fellow’s gone mad, and so have I. We’re in some kind of dream world. Please, somebody, get us out of here!

paragraphs.original: Enter a COURTESAN$NEWLINE$COURTESAN
paragraphs.translated: A COURTESAN enters.$NEWLINE$COURTESAN

paragraphs.original: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Well met, well met, Master Antipholus.$NEWLINE$I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now.$NEWLINE$Is that the chain you promised me today?
paragraphs.translated: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Good to see you, Master Antipholus. I see you’ve met with the jeweler. Is that chain you’re wearing the one you promised to give to me?

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Satan, avoid! I charge thee, tempt me not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Get away from me, Satan! Don’t try to tempt me!

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, is this Mistress Satan?
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, is this Satan’s mistress?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$It is the devil.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$She’s the devil.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Nay, she is worse; she is the devil’s dam, and here she comes in the habit of a light wench. And thereof comes that the wenches say “God damn me” that’s as much to say “God make me a light wench.” It is written they appear to men like angels of light. Light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn: ergo, light wenches will burn. Come not near her.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$No, she’s worse: she’s the devil’s mother, and she comes to us disguised as an easy wench. And that’s why some women say, “God damn me,” which is the same thing as saying, “God make me an easy wench.” The Bible says the devil looks like an angel of light. But fire also gives off light, and fire will burn you. In other words, easy wenches will burn you. Keep away from this one.

paragraphs.original: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Your man and you are marvelous merry, sir.$NEWLINE$Will you go with me? We’ll mend our dinner here.
paragraphs.translated: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$You and your servant are very funny, sir. Will you come with me? Can we finish our lunch?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, if you do, expect spoon meat; or bespeak a long spoon.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Master, if you eat with her, bring really long silverware.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why, Dromio?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Why, Dromio?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with the devil.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Because of the old saying: “He who eats with the devil needs a very long spoon.” You need to keep far away from them.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(to COURTESAN) Avoid then, fiend! What tell’st thou me of supping?$NEWLINE$to$NEWLINE$Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress.$NEWLINE$I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$(to COURTESAN) Get away, you demon! You talk about eating? You’re a sorceress, like everyone else here. I’ll conjure you, like a spell: get away from me.$NEWLINE$to

paragraphs.original: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner$NEWLINE$Or, for my diamond, the chain you promised,$NEWLINE$And I’ll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
paragraphs.translated: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Give me back the ring I gave you at lunch, or give me the necklace you promised in exchange. Then I’ll be gone, sir, and stop troubling you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Some devils ask but the parings of one’s nail, a rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin, a nut, a cherrystone; but she, more covetous, would have a chain. Master, be wise. An if you give it her, the devil will shake her chain and fright us with it.
paragraphs.translated:
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Some
devils ask for nothing more than nail clippings, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin, a nut, or a cherry pit. But this one’s greedy: she wants a necklace. Be wise, master. If you give it to her, she’ll shake the chain and frighten us, like the angel in the Bible.$NEWLINE$devils$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$I pray you, sir, my ring or else the chain.$NEWLINE$I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.
paragraphs.translated: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Now listen, either give me my ring or give me the necklace. I hope you’re not trying to cheat me.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Avaunt, thou witch!—Come, Dromio, let us go.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Be gone, witch! Come, Dromio, let’s go.

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$“Fly pride,” says the peacock. Mistress, that you know.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$Accusing us of cheating is like the proud peacock accusing someone else of pride. Mistress, you know about that.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSE exit.$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

paragraphs.original: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Now, out of doubt Antipholus is mad;$NEWLINE$Else would he never so demean himself.$NEWLINE$A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats,$NEWLINE$And for the same he promised me a chain.$NEWLINE$Both one and other he denies me now.$NEWLINE$The reason that I gather he is mad,$NEWLINE$Besides this present instance of his rage,$NEWLINE$Is a mad tale he told today at dinner$NEWLINE$Of his own doors being shut against his entrance.$NEWLINE$Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits,$NEWLINE$On purpose shut the doors against his way.$NEWLINE$My way is now to hie home to his house$NEWLINE$And tell his wife that, being lunatic,$NEWLINE$He rushed into my house and took perforce$NEWLINE$My ring away. This course I fittest choose,$NEWLINE$For forty ducats is too much to lose.
paragraphs.translated: COURTESAN$NEWLINE$Antipholus has gone insane, no question about it. If not, he’d never behave like this. He has a ring of mine, worth forty ducats, and he promised to give me a necklace in exchange for it. Now he won’t give me either. The reason I think he’s insane, besides the way he just acted, is that he told a senseless story over lunch about being locked out of his own house. His wife probably did it on purpose because she knows what kind of fits he’s having. I must go to his house and tell his wife that he came bursting into my place like a lunatic and stole my ring. It’s my best option: I can’t afford to lose forty ducats.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS and the OFFICER$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$OFFICER
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS enters with the OFFICER.$NEWLINE$ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$OFFICER

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Fear me not, man. I will not break away:$NEWLINE$I’ll give thee, ere I leave thee, so much money,$NEWLINE$To warrant thee, as I am ’rested for.$NEWLINE$My wife is in a wayward mood today$NEWLINE$And will not lightly trust the messenger$NEWLINE$That I should be attached in Ephesus.$NEWLINE$I tell you, ’twill sound harshly in her ears.
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Don’t worry, man, I won’t try to escape. When it’s time for me to be freed, I’ll pay you the fee you’re entitled to for arresting me. My wife’s in a perverse mood today. She’ll be suspicious when the messenger tells her that I was arrested. I tell you, this will make her angry when she hears about it.

paragraphs.original: Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS with a rope’s end$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS enters, holding a length of rope.$NEWLINE$DROMIO OF EPHESUS

paragraphs.original: Here comes my man. I think he brings the money.$NEWLINE$How now, sir? Have you that I sent you for?
paragraphs.translated: Here’s my servant. I think he’s got the money. Hello there, sir! Do you have what I told you to get?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Here’s that, I warrant you, will pay them all.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Yes. And this rope will take care of everybody, I guarantee it.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$But where’s the money?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$But where’s the money?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Why, sir, I spent it on this rope.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Five hundred ducats, villain, for a rope?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$You idiot! Five hundred ducats for a rope?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I’ll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$I can get you five hundred ropes for that price.

paragraphs.original: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?
paragraphs.translated: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$Why did I just send you home?

paragraphs.original: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$To a rope’s end, sir, and to that end am I returned.
paragraphs.translated: DROMIO OF EPHESUS$NEWLINE$To get a piece of rope. And here I am, with that piece.
